{{Infobox military unit |unit_name= 3rd Naval Warfare Flotilla |native_name =''Tredje sjöstridsflottiljen'' |image=3. sjöstridsflottiljen vapen.svg |image_size=120px |caption= |dates= 1983–present |country= [[Sweden]] |allegiance= [[Swedish Armed Forces]] |branch= [[Swedish Navy]] |type= [[Submarine]] |role= |size= [[Flotilla]] |command_structure= {{nowrap|[[Coastal Fleet]] (1977–1994)}}
{{nowrap|[[Milo S|Southern Military Area]] (1994–2000)}}
{{nowrap|[[Joint Forces Command (Sweden)|Joint Forces Command]] (2000–2005)}}
[[Swedish Armed Forces Headquarters|SAFHQ]] (2005–) |garrison=[[Karlskrona]] |garrison_label= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march="Svenska flottan" (Högberg){{#tag:ref|The march was adopted in 2005 when it was inherited from the Second Surface Warfare Flotilla (''Andra ytstridsflottiljen'').{{harvnb|Sandberg|2007|p=42}}|group=note}} |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles= |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |disbanded= |flying_hours= |website= |commander1=Captain Per Edling |commander1_label= |commander2= |commander2_label= |commander3= |commander3_label= |commander4= |commander4_label= |notable_commanders= |identification_symbol=[[File:Tilläggstecken för Tredje ytstridsflottiljen.jpg|100px]] |identification_symbol_label=Military patch (1998–2004) |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= |identification_symbol_3= |identification_symbol_3_label= |identification_symbol_4= |identification_symbol_4_label= }} '''3rd Naval Warfare Flotilla''' ({{lang-sv|Tredje sjöstridsflottiljen}} or ''3. sjöstridsflj'') of the [[Swedish Fleet]] was founded in 2005 when the former [[minelayer]] and surface flotillas joined together. The flotilla's home base is in [[Karlskrona]], [[Blekinge]] and is a part of the [[Karlskrona naval base]]. The flotilla mostly deploy ships in international missions today. ==Organization== The flotilla is split into three different divisions. '''31st Corvett Division''' *{{HSwMS|Stockholm|P11}} patrol boat of [[Stockholm-class corvette|''Stockholm''-class]] *{{HSwMS|Malmö|P12}} patrol boat of [[Stockholm-class corvette|''Stockholm''-class]] *{{HSwMS|Härnösand|K33}} corvett of [[Visby-class corvette|''Visby''-class]] *{{HSwMS|Nyköping|K34}} corvett of [[Visby-class corvette|''Visby''-class]] *{{HSwMS|Karlstad|K35}} corvett of [[Visby-class corvette|''Visby''-class]] *3 patrol boats of the [[Tapper-class patrol boat|''Tapper''-class]] '''33rd Minelayer Division''' *2 minelayer ship of [[Koster-class mine countermeasures vessel|''Koster''-class]]. *1 ship of ''Spårö''-class '''34th Support Division''' *{{HSwMS|Carlskrona|P04}} The former [[missile boat]] division was stationed in the flotilla until September 2005 when all the ships was decommissioned. ==Heraldry and traditions== ===Coat of arms=== The coat of arms of the 3rd Surface Attack Flotilla (''Tredje ytattackflottiljen'') 1997–1998 and 3rd Surface Warfare Flotilla (''Tredje ytstridsflottiljen'' 1998–2004. [[Blazon]]: "Gules, a flash pointing down bendysinister argent, the first field charged with an erect crossbow and the second field with two triangles conjoined in pale, all or".{{harvnb|Braunstein|2006|p=52}} The unit later adopted a new coat of arms. File:Tredje ytstridsflottiljen vapen.svg|Coat of arms of the 3rd Surface Attack Flotilla (''Tredje ytattackflottiljen'') 1997–1998 and 3rd Surface Warfare Flotilla (''Tredje ytstridsflottiljen'') 1998–2004. File:3. sjöstridsflottiljen vapen.svg|Coat of arms of the 3rd Surface Warfare Flotilla (''Tredje ytstridsflottiljen'') and the 3rd Naval Warfare Flotilla (''3. sjöstridsflottiljen''). ===Flag=== The flag is a double swallow-tailed [[Flag of Sweden|Swedish flag]].{{harvnb|Braunstein|2004|p=64}} It was presented to the then 3rd Surface Attack Flotilla by the Supreme Commander [[Owe Wiktorin]] at the Artillery Yard in [[Stockholm]] on 30 April 1996.{{harvnb|Birke|Braunstein|2011|p=89}} ==Commanding officers== {{Div col}} *1983–1984 – Lennart Grenstad *1984–1985 – Lars Thomasson *1985–1988 – [[Frank Rosenius]] *1988–1989 – [[Torsten Lindh]] *1990–1993 – Sölve Larsby *1994–1997 – Magnus Waldenström *1997–1999 – Tommy Åsman *1999–2001 – [[Jörgen Ericsson]] *2001–2002 – Leif Nylander *2003–2005 – [[Anders Grenstad]] *2005–2008 – Erik Andersson *2008–2011 – Anders Olovsson *2012–2015 – Magnus Jönsson{{cite web |url=http://blogg.forsvarsmakten.se/marinbloggen/2011/12/21/forfangning-till-rors-vid-3-sjostridsflottiljen-i-karlskrona/ |publisher=[[Swedish Armed Forces]] |title=Förfångning till rors vid 3.sjöstridsflottiljen i Karlskrona |first=Jan |last=Thörnqvist |author-link=Jan Thörnqvist |date=2011-12-21 |accessdate=16 April 2016 |language=Swedish}} *2016–2018 – Bengt Lundgren{{cite journal |url=http://www.forsvarsmakten.se/siteassets/6-aktuellt/forsvarets-forum/2015/forsvarets-forum-5-2015.pdf |journal=Försvarets forum: personaltidning för fast anställda och reservofficerare i svenska försvarsmakten |title=PÅ NY POST |year=2015 |publisher=Försvarets forum |location=Stockholm |number=5 |page=9 |id={{LIBRIS|4109339}} |access-date=15 April 2016 |language=sv}} *2018–20xx – Per Edling {{Div col end}} ==Names, designations and locations== {| class="wikitable" ! style="font-weight:bold;" | Name ! style="font-weight:bold;" | Translation ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | From ! ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | To |- | style="font-style:italic;" | 4. ytattackflottiljen | 4th Surface Attack Flotilla | 1983-01-01 | – | 1994-06-30 |- | style="font-style:italic;" | 3. ytattackflottiljen | 3rd Surface Attack Flotilla | 1994-07-01 | – | 1997-12-31 |- | style="font-style:italic;" | 3. ytstridsflottiljen | 3rd Surface Warfare Flotilla | 1998-01-01 | – | 2005-08-31 |- | style="font-style:italic;" | 3. sjöstridsflottiljen | 3rd Naval Warfare Flotilla | 2005-09-01 | – | |- ! style="font-weight:bold;" | Designation ! style="font-weight:bold;" | ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | From ! ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | To |- | 4. yaflj | | style="text-align: center;" | 1983-01-01 | style="text-align: center;" | – | style="text-align: center;" | 1994-06-30 |- | 3. yaflj | | style="text-align: center;" | 1994-07-01 | style="text-align: center;" | – | style="text-align: center;" | 1997-12-31 |- | 3. ysflj | | style="text-align: center;" | 1998-01-01 | style="text-align: center;" | – | style="text-align: center;" | 2005-08-31 |- | 3. sjöstridsflj | | style="text-align: center;" | 2005-09-01 | style="text-align: center;" | – | style="text-align: center;" | |- ! style="font-weight:bold;" | Location ! style="font-weight:bold;" | ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | From ! ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | To |- | [[Karlskrona naval base]] | | style="text-align: center;" | 1983-01-01 | style="text-align: center;" | – | style="text-align: center;" | |} ==Footnotes== ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist}} ===Print=== *{{cite book |last1=Birke |first1=Sune |last2=Braunstein |first2=Christian |title=Sveriges marina förband och skolor under 1900-talet |series=Skrift / Statens försvarshistoriska museer, 1101-7023 ; 13 |year=2011 |publisher=Statens försvarshistoriska museer |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=978-91-976220-5-9 |id={{LIBRIS|12638815}} |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |url=https://www.sfhm.se/contentassets/84a6e4f1b2ce4e2b96c4ba578a41c503/sfhm-skriftserie_svenska-armens-falttecken-efter-millennieskiftet_av_christian-braunstein.pdf |last=Braunstein |first=Christian |title=Svenska försvarsmaktens fälttecken efter millennieskiftet |trans-title=The flags and standards of the Swedish Armed Forces after the turn of the millennium |series=Skrift / Statens försvarshistoriska museer, 1101-7023 ; 9 |year=2006 |publisher=Statens försvarshistoriska museer |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=91-971584-9-6 |id={{LIBRIS|10099224}} |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Sandberg |first=Bo |title=Försvarets marscher och signaler förr och nu: marscher antagna av svenska militära förband, skolor och staber samt igenkännings-, tjänstgörings- och exercissignaler |edition=New |year=2007 |publisher=Militärmusiksamfundet med Svenskt marscharkiv |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=978-91-631-8699-8 |id={{LIBRIS|10413065}} |ref=harv}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Tredje sjöstridsflottiljen|3rd Naval Warfare Flotilla}} *{{Official website|https://www.forsvarsmakten.se/sv/organisation/tredje-sjostridsflottiljen/}} {{sv icon}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Category:Naval units and formations of Sweden]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1983]] {{Sweden-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Year in South Africa|Early CE}}
==Events== * 300 AD - Early [[Iron Age]] communities are established in the northern and eastern regions of Southern Africa * 500 AD - A group of [[Bantu languages|Bantu]]-speaking tribes migrating southwards reached present-day [[KwaZulu-Natal Province]] * 696 AD - [[Arab]] traders trade along the east coast of the Southern African region * 1050 - 1270 AD - [[Mapungubwe|Kingdom of Mapungubwe]] * 4th century - Migrants from the north settle, joining the indigenous San and Khoikhoi people.
==References== See [[Years in South Africa]]
[[Category:History of South Africa]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}}{{Infobox Military Unit|unit_name=Army Training and Doctrine Command|image=Army Training and Doctrine Command logo.png|image_size=150px|caption=ARTDOC Insignia|country={{BAN}}|branch={{army|Bangladesh}}|type=[[Formation (military)|Command]]|dates=25 July 2007 – present|specialization=|command_structure=|size=|current_commander=Lt Gen [[Md Nazimuddin]] |garrison=[[Mymensingh Cantonment]]|battles=|notable_commanders=}} '''ARTDOC''' ('''Army Training and Doctrine Command'''){{Cite news|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/06/16/indian-army-chief-takes-salute-of-bangladesh-military-academy-cadets|title=Indian Army chief takes salute of Bangladesh Military Academy cadets|newspaper=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-10-30}} is a research oriented formation in the Bangladesh Army. It is headquartered at Momenshahi Cantonment. It is charged with overseeing training evaluation and reforms; weapon, equipment and force modernization; development of concepts and doctrine revision. It consists of its headquarters, battle group and all the training institutions of the [[Bangladesh Army]]. The pioneer [[General officer commanding|General Officer Commanding]] of ARTDOC was [[Major general|Major General]] [[Md Zia-Ur-Rahman]], ndc, psc.{{cite web|url=http://www.artdoc.mil.bd/profile.php?c_id=p166017494 |title=ARTDOC |website=Army Training and Doctrine Command |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426081423/http://www.artdoc.mil.bd/profile.php?c_id=p166017494 |archive-date=26 April 2012 |deadurl=bot: unknown }}{{Cite web|url=https://www.shephardmedia.com/news/training-simulation/bangladesh-army-receives-sword/|title=Bangladesh Army receives SWORD - News - Shephard|website=www.shephardmedia.com|access-date=2016-10-30}} Current Commander is [[Lieutenant general]] [[Md Nazimuddin]]">{{cite web|url=http://www.theindependentbd.com/printversion/details/160187|title=Shafiqur made CGS, Mujibur new DG of SSF|website=theindependentbd.com|date=July 31, 2018|accessdate=August 2, 2018}} == Mission == The official mission statement for ARTDOC states:
To prepare BD Army for war and be the architect of its future.
== History == In the past, the Military Training (MT) Directorate at Army Headquarters (AHQ) was responsible for carrying out different types of research works related to training of the Bangladesh Army. However, due to limited resources and a manpower shortage, they couldn't do any comprehensive research and study in the field of doctrine and development. To strengthen the research and development capability for strategic, operational, tactical and technological enhancement, and to keep up with continual changes in the complexities of the battlefield scenario, rapid technological advancement Bangladesh Army raised ARTDOC on 25 July 2007 to develop its training and operational standards with special emphasis on research and development in the related fields. == Training Institutions == ARTDOC acts as the nodal agency of all institutional training. Bangladesh Army has 20 different training to train officers and men of all arms and services. * Artillery Centre and School * Armoured Corps Centre and School * East Bengal Regimental Center * Engineer Center and School of Military Engineering * Signals Training Center and School * Army Medical Corps Centre and School * School of Electrical Mechanical Engineering * Ordnance Center and School * Army Service Corps Centre and School * School of Military Intelligence * Army School of Music * Army School of Physical Training and Sports * [[Bangladesh Institute of Peace Support Operation Training]] * Bangladesh Infantry Regimental Centre * [[School of Infantry and Tactics]] * [[Bangladesh Military Academy]] * Army School of Education and Administration * Corps of Military Police Centre and school * [[403 Battle Group (Bangladesh)|403 Battle Group]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-115254|title=Flag raising ceremony of 403 battle group held|date=2009-11-22|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Bangladesh Army]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Bangladesh]] {{Bangladesh-mil-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Africa Finance Corporation | logo = File:AFC logo small.jpg | type = [[Private company|Private]] | owner = African governments
African banks
Private equity funds

[[Ikoyi]], [[Lagos State]], [[Nigeria]] | key_people = '''Joseph Nnana''' (Chairman)
'''Samaila Zubairu''' (President & CEO) | num_employees = | industry = [[Finance]] | products = Development Finance Institution | assets = US$3.4+ billion (2017) http://www.biznisafrica.com/joseph-nnanna-appointed-africa-finance-corporation-chairman/ | revenue = | homepage = [http://www.africafc.org/ www.africafc.org] }} '''Africa Finance Corporation''' ('''AFC''') is a pan-African multilateral development finance institution established in 2007 to bridge Africa’s infrastructure investment gap through the provision of debt and equity finance, project development, technical and financial advisory services.{{cite news |last=Mwaniki |first=Charles |date= 4 March 2014 |title=Africa Finance Corporation secures first global rating |url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Africa-Finance-Corporation-secures-first-global-rating/-/539552/2230848/-/f8os05/-/index.html |newspaper=Business Daily Africa |access-date=15 April 2016}}{{cite news |last=Jacks |first=Mzwandile |date=3 March 2014 |title=AFC Gets Moody’s Credit Rating |url=http://venturesafrica.com/afc-gets-moodys-credit-rating/ |newspaper=Ventures Africa |access-date=15 April 2016}}{{cite news |last=Naso |first=Chelsea |date=29 April 2015 |title= Africa Finance Nabs $750M In Debut Eurobond Offer |url= http://www.law360.com/articles/649426/africa-finance-nabs-750m-in-debut-eurobond-offer |newspaper=Law360 |location=New York |access-date=15 April 2016}} AFC finances infrastructure projects in Africa, focusing in particular on power, transportation, telecommunications, heavy industry and natural resources (oil, gas and mining).{{cite news |last=Nelthorpe |first=Tom |date=30 April 2015 |title=Africa Finance Corporation prices debut Eurobond |url=https://ijglobal.com/articles/96187/africa-finance-corporation-prices-debut-eurobond |newspaper=IJGlobal |location=Sub-Saharan Africa |access-date=15 April 2016}} AFC is majority-owned by private investors, the bulk of which are African financial institutions, which own 47.6% of the corporation. A further 42.5% is owned by the Central Bank of Nigeria. AFC’s nineteen Member States, in order of accession, are Nigeria, Guinea Bissau, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Gambia, Liberia, Guinea, Chad, Cape Verde, Gabon, Côte d'Ivoire, Rwanda, Uganda, Djibouti, Kenya, Zambia, Benin, Malawi and Zimbabwe.{{cite news |last=Agbo |first=Ekele Peter |date=14 July 2015 |title=Nigeria: AFC to Co-Develop U.S.$ 120 Million Singrobo Hydro Power Plant in Côte d'Ivoire | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201507141573.html |newspaper=All Africa |access-date=15 April 2016}}{{cite news |author= |title=Côte d’Ivoire becomes 11th member of Africa Finance Corporation | url=https://www.african-markets.com/en/news/west-africa/ivory-coast/cote-d-ivoire-becomes-11th-member-of-africa-finance-corporation |newspaper=African Markets |date= 19 October 2015| access-date=15 April 2016}}{{cite news | last=Eremionkhale |first=Omono |date=3 December 2015 |title=AFC Gets Two New Member Countries in East Africa |url=http://venturesafrica.com/137098/ |newspaper=Ventures Africa |access-date=15 April 2016}} As of September 2016, AFC has invested US$4.5 billion in projects in 26 African countries.{{cite news |last=Njini |first=Felix |date=14 September 2016 |title=Africa Finance Corp. Plans More Eurobonds for Infrastructure |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-14/africa-finance-corp-plans-more-eurobonds-for-infrastructure |newspaper=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |location= |access-date=18 October 2016}} ==History== ===Early projects=== Africa Finance Corporation (AFC) was launched in December, 2007 by Chukwuma Soludo, then governor of the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN), with US$2 billion of authorised share capital.{{cite news |last1=Marks |first1=Jon |last2=Godier |first2=Kevin |date=12 January 2007 |title=SpecialSupplement:Africa-EmergingAssetClass-ADecadeAfterBigDevelopersPulledBack,Sub-Saharan AfricaIsRe-emergingAsAMarketForInfrastructure Finance,WithInnovationsInInternationalAndLocalMarkets |url=http://www.octasis.com/pdf/06112014084242EmergingAssetClassInSubSaharanAfrica.pdf |newspaper=The Banker |location= |access-date=15 April 2016}} In June, 2009 AFC agreed an equity financing deal with a consortium of investors in the US$240 million Main One Cable System, a 7,000 km submarine fibre-optic cable connecting West Africa to Europe.{{cite news |author= |title=Ghana: AFC-financed Main One Submarine Cable Lands |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201005200668.html |newspaper= All Africa|location= |date=20 May 2010 |access-date=15 April 2016}}{{cite news |author= |title=Main One Cable progresses with equity financing |url=https://www.telegeography.com/products/commsupdate/articles/2009/06/08/main-one-cable-progresses-with-equity-financing/ |newspaper=TeleGeography |location= |date=8 June 2009 |access-date=15 April 2016}} By July 2009, it was reported by Reuters that AFC had US$180 million invested in oil and gas, telecoms, transport and airline projects – mainly in Nigeria.{{cite news |last=Fabi |first=Randy |date=15 July 2009 |title=Nigeria’s AFC investments at $180 mln, eyes more |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/nigeria-bank-afc-idUKLF49952620090715 |newspaper=Reuters |location=Abuja |access-date=15 April 2016}} In September 2011, the corporation partnered with the African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) and Banque Internationale pour l' Afrique Occidentale - Côte d'Ivoire (BIAO-CI) in a US$320 million trade finance facility to finance the importation, processing and refining of crude oil by Societe Ivoirienne de Raffinage (SIR).{{cite news |author= |title=Company Announcement: AFC and Afreximbank sign $320m Trade Finance Facility for Processing and Refining of Crude Oil in Cote d’ Ivoire |url=http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/print-version/company-announcement-afc-and-afreximbank-sign-320m-trade-finance-facility-for-processing-and-refining-of-crude-oil-in-cote-d-ivoire-2011-09-29 |newspaper=Engineering News |location= |date=19 September 2011 |access-date=15 April 2016}} ===Power generation=== In June 2013, AFC announced its support for privatisation of the Nigerian power sector, providing a US$215 million debt financing facility for the acquisition of the Ughelli Power plc by Transcorp.{{cite news |last=Rice |first=Xan |date=25 June 2013 |title=Volatility delays investment from Nigeria sovereign wealth fund |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ad73a00a-ddb3-11e2-892b-00144feab7de.html?siteedition=uk#axzz3hsPRI0m5 |newspaper=Financial Times |location=Lagos |access-date=15 April 2016}} The previous month it had joined Lagos-based Vigeo and India’s Tata Power in a consortium which successfully bid US$129 million for Benin Distribution Company.{{cite news |last=Rice |first=Xan |date=7 May 2013 |title=Vigeo: Lagos-based distributor set for long game |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/3e5721dc-acd6-11e2-9454-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3i7V8r4QX |newspaper=Financial Times |location= |access-date=15 April 2016}} In August 2013, AFC provided a US$170 million loan facility to Nigerian firm Mainstream Energy Solutions Limited (MESL) in its successful bid for the 1,338 MW Kainji Hydroelectric power plant in Niger State, Nigeria.{{cite news |last=Adaramola |first=Kehinde |date=5 August 2013 |title=Powering Nigeria: MESL Partners Investors to Finance Kainji Plant |url=http://venturesafrica.com/powering-nigeria-mesl-partners-investors-to-finance-kainji-plant/ |newspaper=Ventures Africa |location= |access-date=15 April 2016}} At the same time it was invited to become a private sector partner in the US $7 billion USAID-funded ‘Power Africa’ initiative announced by US President Obama in Cape Town.{{cite book |last1=Miller |first1=Scott |last2=Runde |first2=Daniel |date=1 January 2014 |title=A New Development Agenda: Trade, Development, and Procurement |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cS8EAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA16&lpg=PA16&dq=%22power+africa%22+africa+finance+corporation&source=bl&ots=7HGuxSoklT&sig=TAIGQXBCT_qGQXu91-QGxYoL6pQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAzgKahUKEwje4PLtlJDHAhXI7xQKHeEsAH4#v=onepage&q=%22power%20africa%22%20africa%20finance%20corporation&f=false |location= |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |page=16 |isbn=978-1-4422-2810-8}} AFC has since invested US$250 million and leveraged an additional US$1billion of investments in the power sectors of Ghana, Kenya and Nigeria.{{cite news |last=Longman |first=Nye |date=30 March 2015 |title=Africa Finance Corporation announces record profits |url=http://www.africanbusinessreview.co.za/finance/1886/Africa-Finance-Corporation-announces-record-profits |newspaper=African Business Review |location= |access-date=15 April 2016}} In December 2014, AFC took a 23.2% stake in Mozambican power developer Ncondezi Energy.{{cite news |author= |title=AFC to take stake in Ncondezi Energy |url=http://www.thebusinessdesk.com/yorkshire/afc-to-take-stake-in-ncondezi-energy.html |newspaper=The Business Desk |location= |date=15 December 2014 |access-date=15 April 2016}} Also in December 2014, AFC became the largest investor and lead developer in the US$900 million Kpone Independent Power Project (Kpone IPP) in Ghana, which comprises a 350MW gas turbine, a substation and fuel storage.{{cite news |author= |title=AFC initiates $900m power project in Ghana |url=http://guardian.ng/business-services/business/afc-initiates-900m-power-project-in-ghana/ |newspaper=The Guardian |location= |date=2 February 2015 |access-date=15 April 2016}} In July 2015, the corporation signed a joint development agreement with the Ivorian project company Ivoire Hydro Energy SA (IHE) to build a 44MW hydroelectric power plant in Singrobo, Côte d'Ivoire. The same month AFC became the first African development finance institution to be accredited as a partnering institution by the Green Climate Fund.{{cite news |author= |title=Green Climate Fund completes accreditation of Africa Finance Corporation |url=http://www.greentechlead.com/sustainability/green-climate-fund-completes-accreditation-of-africa-finance-corporation-24764 |newspaper= Greentechlead.com |location= |date=17 July 2015 |access-date=15 April 2016}} In June 2016, AFC and institutional investor Harith General Partners merged their power sector assets to form a new entity combining renewable and non-renewable power generating assets in Africa. The new joint venture, which supplies power to over 30 million people, has more than US$3.3billion in assets – including Kpone Independent Power Project in Ghana, Azura Edo in Nigeria and Lake Turkana Wind Power in Kenya – with a combined gross operational and under-construction capacity of 1,575 MW.{{cite news |last=Cotterill |first=Joseph |date=22 June 2016 |title= Investors combine to create pan-African energy group |access-date=16 October 2016| url= https://www.ft.com/content/8b04683a-37cc-11e6-a780-b48ed7b6126f |newspaper=[[Financial Times]] |location=London}} ==Financing== AFC signed its first loan – a US$50 million bilateral deal with Standard Bank – in July 2011.{{cite news |author= |title=Africa Finance Corporation signs maiden loan and plans assault on bond market |url=http://www.globalcapital.com/article/jbwtpghjh4wn/africa-finance-corporation-signs-maiden-loan-and-plans-assault-on-bond-market |newspaper=Global Capital |location= |date=28 July 2011 |access-date=15 April 2016}} The following year the African Development Bank (AfDB) approved a US$200 million line of credit to AFC with the mandate to catalyse investments and help bridge Africa’s infrastructure gap.{{cite news |author= |title=AfDB Approves U.S.$ 200M Line of Credit to Africa Finance Corporation for Infrastructure Support |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201203131251.html |newspaper=All Africa |location= |date=13 March 2012 |access-date=15 April 2016}} In October 2013, AFC launched its first syndicated loan – a US$250 million deal with Citibank, Rand Merchant Bank, Standard Bank, and Standard Chartered Bank – to finance trade projects.{{cite news |author= |title=AFC in debut syndicated loan success |url=https://tradefinanceanalytics.com/Articles/3291841/AFC-in-debut-syndicated-loan-success |newspaper=Trade Finance |location= |date=20 December 2013 |access-date=15 April 2016}} In March 2014, the corporation received its first international credit rating from Moody’s Investors Services, which assigned an A3 long-term foreign currency debt rating.{{cite news |last=Saigal |first=Kanika |date= |title= AFC inaugural Eurobond benefirts from Nigeria’s post-election relief |url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/3451932/Category/11/ChannelPage/8959/AFC-inaugural-Eurobond-benefits-from-Nigerias-post-election-relief.html |newspaper=Euro Money |location= |access-date=15 April 2016}} In April 2015, AFC issued a five-year debut US$750 million Eurobond, attracting US$4.7 billion in bids from institutional investors across Asia, Europe and the US. The bond issue was the first under a US$3 billion global medium-term note programme.{{cite news |author= |title=Finance: Africa Corp debut $750 million Eurobond sees heavy demand |url=http://www.theafricareport.com/West-Africa/finance-africa-finance-corp-debut-750-million-eurobond-sees-heavy-demand.html |newspaper=The Africa Report |location= |date=29 April 2015 |access-date=15 April 2016}} In June 2016, AFC borrowed US$150 million for 15 years from [[KfW]], for onward lending in the sectors of power, telecommunications, transport and heavy industry.{{cite web|accessdate=26 June 2016|last=Press Release| url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201606231132.html|date= 22 June 2016| title=Africa: AFC Receives U.S.$150 Million From KFW Development Bank| publisher=African Media Agency via [[AllAfrica.com]]|location=Dubai}} In January 2017, AFC issued its maiden US$150 million sukuk, which attracted subscriptions of up to US$230 million http://af.reuters.com/article/investingNews/idAFKBN1581I8. In April 2017, AFC issued a US$500 million 7 year Eurobond. The Corporation’s second Eurobond, it was a five times over-subscribed, attracting US$2.4 billion from 231 investors across the Middle East, Asia, the United Kingdom, Europe and the United States http://af.reuters.com/article/investingNews/idAFKBN1581I8. ==Projects== '''Power''' *Cen Power Kpone IPP in Ghana{{cite news |author= |title=AFC funded $900m Kpone power plant to be unveiled this week |url=https://www.ghanabusinessnews.com/2015/01/28/afc-funded-900m-kpone-power-plant-to-be-unveiled-this-week/ |newspaper=Ghana Business News |location= |date=28 January 2015 |access-date=16 October '''''Biruința''''' ([[Romanian language|Romanian]] equivalent for ''Victory''), renamed '''''Iris Star''''' and later '''''Histria Crown''''', is a Romanian crude oil tanker.
==History== The ''Biruința'', one of the biggest ships of the Romanian commercial fleet, was sold after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]] and after 6 years of service. The ship was then re-registered under the Maltese flag as ''M/T IRIS STAR''. Administered by Histria Ship Management, the tanker had a 150,000 T.D.W. capacity.
On July 27, 2000, the ship lost power due to engine failure and drifted towards Kandilli point in [[Turkey]]. There was no extensive damage reported. The sister ship of the ''Iris Star'', [[M/T Independenţa|M/T ''Independența'']], suffered a more deadly accident with a Greek ship (''M/V Evriyali'') at the southern entrance to the Strait of [[Istanbul]]. After colliding, all but three members of the Romanian tanker crew lost their lives.
In 2005, ''Biruința'' was renamed the ''Histria Crown''.
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050204153113/http://histria.ro/ships/Histria%20Crown.htm The Histria Crown] on the site of the shipping company Histria.

{{BLP sources|date=July 2017}} '''Deepa M. Ollapally''' is research professor of international affairs and the associate director of the [[Sigur Center for Asian Studies]] at the [[Elliott School of International Affairs]], [[George Washington University]]. She is also the director of the Rising Powers Initiative launched by the Elliott School in 2009.
== Academic career == Ollapally holds a Ph.D. in Political Science from [[Columbia University]]. Ollapally joined George Washington University in 2003. She directed the South Asia program at the [[U.S. Institute of Peace]] from 1998-2003, and taught at Swarthmore College from 1990-97. From 1996-98, Ollapally served as fellow of the Strategic Studies Unit at the National Institute of Advanced Studies in Bangalore, India.
Her research has focused on security and politics in Asia, particularly nuclear nonproliferation, extremism, gender, and identity politics in the region. Her current research focuses on domestic foreign policy debates in India and their implications for regional security and global leadership of the United States. She is an advisory council member for Women in Security, Conflict Management and Peace, New Delhi, and served on the board of directors for Women in International Security, Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consultative Committee |url=http://www.wiscomp.org/consultative_committee.asp |publisher=Women in Security, Conflict Management and Peace |accessdate=13 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110416114833/http://www.wiscomp.org/consultative_committee.asp |archivedate=16 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> She is a familiar face in discussions and debates on foregin policy in India and abroad.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kochi/make-in-india-will-clash-with-donald-trumps-make-in-america/articleshow/56369579.cms|title='Make in India will clash with Donald Trump's Make in America' - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-11-24}}</ref>
== Selected publications == * (co-ed. with Henry R. Nau) ''Worldviews of Aspiring Powers: Domestic Foreign Policy Debates in China, India, Iran, Japan, and Russia'' (Oxford University Press, 2012). Review by G. John Ikenberry, ''Foreign Affairs'', January/February 2013ISBN 0199985995 * ''The Politics of Extremism in South Asia'' (Cambridge University Press, 2008) {{ISBN|0521875846}}
== Personal life == Ollapally is married to [[G. "Anand" Anandalingam]], dean of the [[Imperial College Business School]] at Imperial College London, and is the mother of two children and owner of a beagle mix dog named Dash.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://elliott.gwu.edu/faculty/ollapally.cfm George Washington University faculty page] * [http://www.risingpowersinitiative.org/ Rising Powers Initiative]

[[File:Turda palais princier musée d'histoire.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Turda Museum]] [[File:TurdaMuseum2008.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Turda Museum]] '''Franziska Tesaurus''' is the richest [[Gepid]] royal tomb found in [[Romania]]. It was found while searching the [[Potaissa (castra)|Potaissa Roman castrum]] at [[Turda]] in 1996, by [[Mihai Bărbulescu]], between the secondary sewer and the [[frigidarium]]. The inventory of the tomb was composed of: polyhedral golden rings with [[almandine]], [[hemicyclical]] gold plated brooch, gold-plated silver belt with gold garments and almandine, amber necklace, embroidery decorations, bone comb, nomadic mirror, silver shoe belts, and small fragments of clothing.
It was put on display on 3 April 2007 in [[Turda History Museum]].
== See also == * [[Apahida necropolis]] * [[Romania in the Early Middle Ages]] * [[Gepids]] * [[Kingdom of the Gepids]]

The '''Growth Research Unit''' ('''GRU''') is a [[Non-profit organization|non-for-profit association]] headquartered in the international programmes office, at the [[Cracow University of Economics]] in [[Poland]]. The association operates as a multi-disciplinary platform, encouraging [[discussion]] and [[research]] into the strategic determinants of [[economic growth]] in respect of the former [[Socialism|socialist]] countries of CE Europe and SE Asia. These goals are achieved through an annual [[Meeting|conference]] meeting at which members contribute to round table discussion sessions and present [[Academic paper|research papers]] prior to release for publication.
== Membership ==
GRU welcomes new members interested in working on challenging theoretical and [[Applied economics|applied economic]] issues as well as on related fields, which focus on the emerging countries of CE Europe and SE Asia.
Membership automatically provides full access to all research publications as well as the opportunity to meet other members with shared interests at our annual conference and round table sessions (October each year).
== Future events ==

| trans_band = 12 [[IEEE]] [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] (NATO [[G band (NATO)|G/H-band]]) | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = 36 MHz | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW =
| programme = ''Intelsat IV'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat III F-7]] (Intelsat III) | next_mission = [[Intelsat IV F-2]] }} '''Intelsat IV F-1''' was a [[geostationary]] [[communication]] [[satellite]] built by [[Hughes Aircraft Company|Hughes]], it was owned by [[Intelsat]]. The satellite was based on the [[Spacebus|HS-312]] platform and its estimated useful life was 7 years.
== History == The Intelsat IV F-1 was part of the Intelsat IV series which consisted of eight communications satellites, launched from [[Cape Canaveral]] during the early 1970s, marked the fifth generation of geostationary communications satellites developed by the [[Hughes Aircraft Company]] since 1963 with the launch of Syncom II, the world's first synchronous satellite. The [[Syncom]] II was 15 cm high and 28 inches in diameter, weighing 78 pounds in orbit. In contrast, the Intelsat IVs weighed more than 1,300 [[Pound (mass)|lb]] (595 kg) into orbit and were more than 17 feet (5.31 meters) in diameter. All seven satellites exceeded their projected life expectancies and were withdrawn from active duty, the last of which, the Intelsat IV F-1 was retired in October 1987.
The satellite was equipped with 12 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] transponders. It had 6,000 two-way [[relay]] phone calls or broadcast 12 concurrent color television programs or mixed combinations of communications traffic including data and fax.
The satellite had 12 channels of broadband communication. Each channel had a bandwidth of 40 MHz and provided about 500 communication circuits.
== Release == The satellite was successfully launched into space on May 22, 1975, by means of an [[Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]] in [[Florida]], [[United States]]. It had a launch mass of 3,117 lb.<ref>Krebs, Gunter. [http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-4a.htm Intelsat-4A]. ''Gunter's Space Page''. Retrieved 21 April 2017.</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Norway}} "Lykken er" | image = [[File:Lykken_er_1971.jpg|250 px]] | caption = | year = 1971 | country = Norway | artist = [[Hanne Krogh]] | as = | with = | language = Norwegian | languages = | composer = [[Arne Bendiksen]] | lyricist = [[Arne Bendiksen]] | conductor = [[Arne Bendiksen]] | place = 17th | points = 65 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1971no from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev_year = 1969 | prev = Oj, oj, oj, så glad jeg skal bli | prev_link = Oj, oj, oj, så glad jeg skal bli | next = Småting | next_link = Småting }} '''"Lykken er"''' ("Happiness is", the title is often rendered with an ellipsis) was the [[Norway|Norwegian]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1971]], performed in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] by [[Hanne Krogh]].
The song is a moderately up-tempo number, with Krogh describing what she sees as examples of happiness - a series of small pleasures such as "an old hat/Which used to belong to your best friend" and "breakfast in bed".
During Preview Week, Krogh was shown singing her song sitting on top of a cliff, standing on roofs, walking down the pier in her hometown, and running with local children. On the night of the Contest, she sang the song in a ball gown, with elbow-length gloves and a [[parasol]], which was used as a prop of sorts at different points in the song.
The song was performed eighteenth (last) on the night, following [[Finland]]'s [[Markku Aro & Koivistolaiset]] with "[[Tie uuteen päivään]]". At the close of voting, it had received 65 points, placing 17th in a field of 18. The relatively high score for such a low finish is due to the voting structure in place at the time, where each entrant was effectively guaranteed 34 points.
It was succeeded as [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest|Norwegian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1972|1972 contest]] by [[Grethe & Benny]] with "[[Småting]]".
{{Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1971}}

{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox Network |network_name = Malawi Broadcasting Corporation |name = |network_logo = |logo = |image = |network_type = [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast]] [[radio]] and [[television]] |branding = |airdate = |country = {{Flagicon|Malawi}} [[Malawi]] |available = |founded = June 8, 1964 |founder = |slogan = |motto = |market_share = |license_area = |broadcast_area = National |area = |erp = |owner = [[Government of Malawi]] |key_people = |foundation = |launch_date = 1964 |closure_date = |dissolved = |past_names = |digital = yes |analog = |servicename1 = |service1 = |servicename2 = |service2 = |servicename3 = |service3 = |servicename4 = |service4 = |callsigns = |callsign = |callsign_meaning = |former_callsigns = |affiliates = |groups = |affiliation = |affiliations = |former_affiliations = |website = {{URL|http://www.mbc.mw}} |footnotes = }} The '''Malawi Broadcasting Corporation''' is a state-run radio company in [[Malawi]]. It was founded in 1964. It has two [[radio station]]s, Radio 1 and Radio 2, and transmits on [[FM broadcasting|FM]], [[Medium Wave]] and [[Shortwave]] frequencies and Online.
It also runs the national television station, [[Television Malawi]].
Its headquarters is in [[Blantyre, Malawi]].

{{Redirect2|King of Siam|The King of Siam|the King and I character|The King and I#Principal roles and notable performers|the novel|Anna and the King of Siam (novel)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox monarchy | royal_title = King | realm = Thailand | native_name = พระมหากษัตริย์ไทย | coatofarms =King's Standard of Thailand.svg | coatofarmscaption = [[Royal Standard of Thailand|Standard of the King]] | image = File:King Rama X official (crop).png | incumbent = [[Vajiralongkorn|Maha Vajiralongkorn]] (Rama X) | incumbentsince = 13 October 2016{{cite news|last1=Campbell|first1=Charlie|title=Thais Face an Anxious Wait to See How Their New King Will Wield His Power|url=http://time.com/4587099/thailand-king-bhumibol-adulyadej-maha-vajiralongkorn-crown-property-bureau/|accessdate=2 December 2016|work=Time|date=n.d.}} | his/her = His | heir_apparent = | first_monarch = [[Sri Indraditya|Sri Indraditya of Sukhothai]] | date = 1238 | residence =[[Grand Palace]] {{small|(ceremonial)}}
[[Dusit Palace]] {{small|(residential)}} | website = [http://brh.thaigov.net Bureau of the Royal Household] }} {{Politics of Thailand}} The '''monarchy of Thailand''' (whose monarch is referred to as the '''King of Thailand''' or historically as the '''King of Siam'''; {{lang-th|พระมหากษัตริย์ไทย)}} refers to the [[constitutional monarchy]] and monarch of the [[Thailand|Kingdom of Thailand]] (formerly [[Siam]]). The King of Thailand is the [[head of state]] and head of the ruling Royal [[House of Chakri]]. Although the current [[Chakri Dynasty]] was created in 1782, the existence of the institution of monarchy in Thailand is traditionally considered to have its roots from the founding of the [[Sukhothai Kingdom]] in 1238, with a brief [[interregnum]] from the death of [[Ekkathat]] to the accession of [[Taksin]] in the 18th century. The institution was transformed into a [[constitutional monarchy]] in 1932 after the bloodless [[Siamese Revolution of 1932]]. The monarchy's official ceremonial residence is the [[Grand Palace]] in [[Bangkok]], while the private residence has been at the [[Dusit Palace]]. The King of Thailand's titles include [[Head of State]], [[Head of the Royal Thai Armed Forces]], Adherent of [[Buddhism in Thailand|Buddhism]] and Upholder of [[Religion in Thailand|religions]].{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.go.th/th_senate/English/constitution2007.pdf|title=Constitution of the Kingdom of Thailand B.E 2550|author=[[House of Representatives (Thailand)|The Secretariate of the House of Representatives]]|publisher=[[House of Representatives (Thailand)|The Secretariat of the House of Representatives]]|date=Nov 2007|accessdate=7 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831223113/http://www.senate.go.th/th_senate/English/constitution2007.pdf|archivedate=31 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} ==History== ===Origin=== {{Further information|Buddhist kingship|Bhāruci|Devaraja|Maha Sammata|Mandala (Southeast Asian political model)|Mandate of Heaven|Monarchy in ancient India||}} The current concept of Thai kingship evolved through 800 years of absolute rule. The first king of a unified [[Thailand]] was the founder of the [[Kingdom of Sukhothai]], King [[Sri Indraditya]], in 1238.{{cite journal |author= | last = Cœdès | first = G.| authorlink1 = Georges Coedès|year= 1921 |title= The Origins of the Sukhodaya Dynasty |journal= [[Journal of the Siam Society]] |volume= JSS Vol. 14.1b |issue= digital |page= image 1|publisher= Siam Heritage Trust |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1921/JSS_014_1b_Coedes_OriginsOfSukhodayaDynasty.pdf |accessdate= 17 March 2013 |quote=The dynasty which reigned during a part of the XIIIth. and the first half of the XlVth. centuries at Sukhodaya and at Sajjanlaya, on the upper Menam Yom, is the first historical Siamese dynasty. It has a double claim to this title, both because its cradle was precisely in the country designated by foreigners as "Siam" (Khmer: Syain; Chinese : Sien, etc.), and because it is this dynasty which, by freeing the Thai principalities from the Cambodian yoke and by gradually extending its conquests as far as the Malay Peninsula, paved the way for the formation of the Kingdom of Siam properly so called.}} The idea of this early kingship is said to be based on two concepts derived from [[Hinduism]] and [[Theravada Buddhism|Theravada Buddhist]] beliefs. The first concept is based on the [[Varna (Hinduism)|Vedic-Hindu caste]] of "[[Kshatriya]]" ({{lang-th|กษัตริย์)}}, or warrior-ruler, in which the king derives his powers from military might. The second is based on the Theravada Buddhist concept of "Dhammaraja" ({{lang-th|ธรรมราชา)}}, Buddhism having been introduced to Thailand around the 6th century CE. The idea of the Dhammaraja (or kingship under Dharma), is that the king should rule his people in accordance with [[Dharma (Buddhism)|Dharma]] and the teachings of the Buddha. These ideas were briefly replaced in 1279, when King [[Ram Khamhaeng the Great|Ramkhamhaeng]] came to the throne. Ramkhamhaeng departed from tradition and created instead a concept of "[[paternal rule]]" ({{lang-th|พ่อปกครองลูก)}}, in which the king governs his people as a father would govern his children.{{cite web |url=http://sunsite.au.ac.th/thailand/thai_monarchy/background.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926091434/http://sunsite.au.ac.th/thailand/thai_monarchy/background.html |archivedate=26 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite journal |author= |last= Prince Dhani Nivat |first= Kromamun Bidyadabh |authorlink= :th:พระวรวงศ์เธอ พระองค์เจ้าธานีนิวัต กรมหมื่นพิทยลาภพฤฒิยากร |year= 1947 |title= The Old Siamese conception of the Monarchy |journal= [[Journal of the Siam Society]] |volume= JSS Vol. 36.2b |issue= digital |page= |pages= image 10 page 93 |publisher= Siamese Heritage Trust |doi= |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1941/JSS_036_2b_PrinceDhani_OldSiameseConceptionOfMonarchy.pdf|accessdate= 7 March 2013 |quote= '''Patriarchal Sukhothai Kingship''' ...The monarch was of course the people's leader in battle; but he was also in peace-time their father whose advice was sought and expected in all matters and whose judgment was accepted by all. He was moreover accessible to his people, for we are told by an old inscription that, in front of the royal palace of Sukhothai there used to be a gong hung up for people to go and beat upon whenever they wanted personal help and redress. The custom survived with slight modifications all through the centuries down to the change of regime in 1932....}} This idea is reinforced in the title and name of the king, as he is still known today, ''[[Pho Khun]] Ramkhamhaeng'' ({{lang-th|พ่อขุนรามคำแหง)}}{{cite journal |author=|last= Terwiel|first= Barend Jan|year= 1983 |title= Ahom and the Study of Early Thai Society|journal= Journal of the Siam Society |volume= JSS Vol. 71.0 |issue= PDF |page= image 4 |publisher= Siamese Heritage Trust |doi= |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1981/JSS_071_0g_Terwiel_AhomAndStudyOfEarlyTaiSociety.pdf |accessdate= 7 March 2013 |quote= In older usage, ''khun'' was used for a ruler of a fortified town and its surrounding villages, together called a [[mueang]]; with the prefix ''pho'' ({{lang|th|พ่อ "father"}}) appears as '''Pho Khun'''.}} meaning 'Father Ruler Ramkhamhaeng'. This lasted briefly. By the end of the kingdom, the two old concepts returned as symbolized by the change in the style of the kings: "Pho" was changed to "Phaya" or Lord. ===Kings of Ayutthaya=== [[File:Birmanie 2. battle betwenn Burmese and Siamese ok fini +.jpg|thumb|right|King [[Naresuan]] of Ayutthaya fought several wars against the Burmese to preserve Siamese independence.]] The Kingdom of Sukhothai was supplanted by the [[Kingdom of Ayutthaya]], which was founded in 1351 by King [[Uthong|Ramathibodhi I]]. During the Ayutthayan period, the idea of kingship changed. Due to ancient Khmer tradition in the region, the Hindu concept of kingship was applied to the status of the leader. Brahmins took charge in the [[Coronation of the Thai monarch|royal coronation]]. The king was treated as a [[reincarnation]] of [[Hindu gods]]. Ayutthaya historical documents show the official titles of the kings in great variation: [[Indra]], [[Shiva]] and [[Vishnu]], or [[Rama]]. Seemingly, Rama was the most popular, as in "Ramathibodhi". However, Buddhist influence was also evident, as many times the king's title and "unofficial" name "Dhammaraja", an abbreviation of the [[Dharmaraja (Buddhism)|Buddhist Dharmaraja]]. The two former concepts were re-established, with a third, older concept taking hold. This concept was called "[[Devaraja]]" ({{lang-th|เทวราชา)}} (or "divine king"), which was an idea borrowed by the [[Khmer Empire]] from the [[Java#Hindu-Buddhist kingdoms era|Hindu-Buddhist kingdoms of Java]], especially the idea of a scholar class based on Hindu [[Brahmins]]. The concept centered on the idea that the king was an incarnation ([[avatar]]) of the god [[Vishnu]] and that he was a [[Bodhisattva]] (enlightened one), therefore basing his power on his religious power, his moral power, and his purity of blood. The king, portrayed by state interests as a semi-divine figure, then became—through a rigid cultural implementation—an object of worship and veneration to his people. From then on the monarchy was largely removed from the people and continued under a system of absolute rule. Living in palaces designed after [[Mount Meru]] ("home of the gods" in Hinduism), the kings turned themselves into a "[[Chakravartin]]", where the king became an absolute and universal lord of his realm. Kings demanded that the universe be envisioned as [[Mandala (political model)|revolving around them]], and expressed their powers through elaborate rituals and ceremonies. For four centuries these kings ruled Ayutthaya, presiding over some of the greatest period of cultural, economic, and military growth in [[History of Thailand|Thai History]]. ===={{anchor|Rachasap}} Sakdina and Rachasap ==== [[File:3 Chedis of Wat Phra Sri Sanphet.JPG|thumb|left|[[Wat Phra Si Sanphet]] next to the king's palace was the most sacred temple in the kingdom of Ayutthaya.]] The Kings of Ayutthaya created many institutions to support their rule. Whereas [[feudalism]] developed in the [[European Middle Ages]], Ayutthayan King [[Trailokanat]] instituted ''[[sakdina]]'', a system of social hierarchy which ranked the king's subjects according to the amount of land they were entitled to, according to their rank and position.{{cite journal|author= | last1 = Griswold | first1 = A.B. | authorlink1 = | last2 = Prasert na Nagara | first2 = | authorlink2 = |year= 1969 |title= A Law Promulgated by the King of Ayudhya in 1397 A.D. Epigraphic and Historical Studies, No. 4 |journal= Journal of the Siam Society |volume= JSS Vol. 57.1 |issue= digital |page= image 3 |publisher= Siam Heritage Trust |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1961/JSS_057_1e_GriswoldPrasert_LawPromulgatedByKingOfAyudhya1397.pdf |accessdate= 17 March 2013 |quote= It was customary for Southeast Asian kings, who were of course the absolute proprietors of the land, to allot the [[usufruct]] of portions of it to their subjects. The kings of Ayudhya allotted a specified number of sakti-na or 'dignity-marks' to each of their subjects according to his rank and the position he occupied, corresponding to the number of ''[[rai (unit)|rai]]'' he was actually or theoretically entitled to; and when the system was fully developed the number of marks ranged from 5 to 25 for ordinary citizens, up to 10,000 for ministers in charge of important departments, and 20,000 for princes of the highest rank.}} ''[[Rachasap]]'' is required by court etiquette as an [[Thai honorifics#Honorific registers|honorific register]] consisting of a special vocabulary used exclusively for addressing the king, or for talking about royalty.{{cite web |url= http://thai-language.com/id/590084/ |title= Royal Words|author= |date= 9 October 2013 |website= Internet resource for the Thai language |publisher= |accessdate= 4 October 2013|quote= }} ==== Royal authority ==== The king was chief administrator, chief legislator, and chief judge, with all laws, orders, verdict and punishments theoretically originating from his person. The king's [[sovereign]]ty was reflected in the titles "Lord of the Land" ({{lang|th|พระเจ้าแผ่นดิน}} ''Phra Chao Phaen Din'') and "Lord of Life" ({{lang|th|เจ้าชีวิต}} ''Chao Chiwit''). The king's powers and titles were seen by foreign observers as proof that the king was an [[absolute monarchy|absolute monarch]] in the European sense. However, in Siamese tradition the duty and responsibility of the king was seen as developed from the [[Monarchy in ancient India#Authority of the King|ancient Indian theories of royal authority]], which resemble [[Enlightened Absolutism]], although the emphasis is not on [[rationality]] but on [[Dhamma]].{{cite journal |author= | last = Lingat | first = R. | authorlink = Robert Lingat |year= 1950|title= Evolution of the Conception of Law in Burma and Siam|journal= [[Journal of the Siam Society]] |volume= JSS Vol. 38.1c |issue= digital |page= |pages= |publisher= Siam Heritage Trust |doi= |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1941/JSS_038_1c_Lingat_EvolutionOfTheConceptionOfLawInBurmaAndSiam.pdf |accessdate= 17 March 2013 |quote= Kings and [[raja]]s are only responsible for keeping peace and order. It is a very noticeable thing that in so rich a language as Sanskrit there exists no proper word to translate our word law as meaning positive law. It is true Hindus have the word darma, which is sometimes wrongfully translated by the word law, but actually is quite a different thing....}} This was disrupted in 1767, when Thai digests of the [[Dhammasattha|dhammasāt]] ({{lang|th|ธรรมศาสตร์}}) were lost when a [[Burma|Burmese]] army under the [[Alaungpaya Dynasty]] invaded, sacked and burned the city of [[Ayutthaya Kingdom#The final phase|Ayutthaya]]. ===Kingdom restored=== {{expand section|date=March 2013}} An interlude filled by civil war was ended when [[Taksin|King Taksin]] restored the dominion under what has been called the [[Thonburi Kingdom]]. ===Chakri kings=== [[File:Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Thongduang, later King [[Rama I]] of Siam, founded the Chakri dynasty in 1782.]] In 1782, [[Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke|King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke]] ascended the throne and moved the capital from the [[Thonburi]] side to the [[History of Bangkok|Bangkok]] side of the [[Chao Phraya River]]. There he established the [[House of Chakri]], the current ruling dynasty of Thailand. (This first reign was later designated as that of Rama I in the list of [[Rama (Kings of Thailand)|Rama Kings of Thailand]].) He also established the office of [[Supreme Patriarch of Thailand|Supreme Patriarch]] as the head of the [[Sangha (Buddhism)|Sangha]], the order of [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] [[bhikkhu|monk]]s. During the [[Rattanakosin era|Rattanakosin Period]] the Chakri kings tried to continue the concepts of Ayutthayan kingship once again emphasizing the connection between the sovereign and his subjects. On the other hand, they continued to not relinquish any authority of the throne. Kings [[Buddha Loetla Nabhalai]] (Rama II) and [[Nangklao]] (Rama III) created a semblance of a modern administration by creating a supreme council and appointing chief officers to help with the running of the government.{{cite book |last= Roberts |first= Edmund |authorlink= Edmund Roberts (diplomat) |title= Embassy to the Eastern courts of Cochin-China, Siam, and Muscat : in the U. S. sloop-of-war Peacock ... during the years 1832-3-4 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=aSgPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA302 |date= 12 October 2007 |origyear= First published in 1837 |publisher= Harper & brothers |location= |oclc= |page= 302 |pages= |nopp= |chapter= Chapter XIX―titles of the king |accessdate= 28 January 2013 |quote= At the head of the Siamese administration is the supreme council, consisting of the following officers:....}} [[Mongkut#Monastic life and Thammayut sect|Mongkut]] (Rama IV) marked a significant break in tradition when he spent the first 27 years of his adult life as a [[Bhikkhu|Buddhist monk]] during which time he became proficient in the English language, before ascending the throne. As king, he continued the appointment of officers to his supreme council, the most notable being [[Thai royal and noble titles#Somdet Chao Phraya|Somdet Chao Phraya]] [[Prayurawongse]] and [[Si Suriyawongse]], both of whom acted as Chief Ministers for King Mongkut (and the latter as [[regent]], from the king's death in 1868 until 1873.) [[Chulalongkorn]] (Rama V) ascended the throne as a minor at age 15 in 1868, and as King of Siam on 16 November 1873. As a prince, he had been tutored in Western traditions by the [[governess]], [[Anna Leonowens]].{{efn|This tutelage has been the source for several fictionalised accounts in the media, most notably the films ''[[The King and I]]'' (1951) and ''[[Anna and the King]]'' (1999), both of which have been banned in Thailand as being disrespectful to the king.}} Intent on reforming the monarchy along Western lines, during his minority he traveled extensively to observe western administrative methods. He transformed the monarchy along Western lines of an "[[Enlightened absolutism|enlightened ruler]]". He abolished the practice of [[Chulalongkorn#Abolition of prostration|prostration]] in front of the monarch, and repealed many laws concerning the relationship between the monarch and his people, while continuing many of the ancient aspects and rituals of the old kingship.{{cite book |last= Wales |first= H. G. Quaritch |authorlink= Horace Geoffrey Quaritch Wales |title= Siamese state ceremonies |url= https://archive.org/details/siamesestatecere030661mbp |date= 14 April 2005 |origyear= First published in 1931 |publisher= Bernard Quaritch |location= London |oclc= |page= 32 |chapter= Chapter IV, the kingship |chapterurl= https://archive.org/stream/siamesestatecere030661mbp/siamesestatecere030661mbp_djvu.txt |accessdate= 25 April 2012 |edition= digital |quote= ...to-day we find the only certain relic of the cult of the Royal God in the symbolism of the Coronation Ceremony by which the Brahman priests call down the spirits of Visnu and Siva to animate the new king....}} In 1874, he created a [[Privy Council of Thailand|privy council]] copied from the European tradition, to help him rule his Kingdom. During his reign Siam was pressured to relinquish control of its old tributaries of Laos and northern Malaya to Western powers, Siam itself narrowly avoided being colonized.{{cite journal |author= | last = Stuart-Fox | first = Martin | authorlink = |year= 1994|title= Conflicting conceptions of the state: Siam, France and Vietnam in the late nineteenth century |journal= [[Journal of the Siam Society]] |volume= JSS Vol. 82.0 |format= free|issue= digital |page= |pages= |nopp= |publisher= Siam Heritage Trust |doi= |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1991/JSS_082_0l_StuartFox_ConflictingConceptionsOfState.pdf|accessdate= 12 April 2013 |quote= Historians of Southeast Asia often face problems in using terms drawn from and applicable to European polities and societies to refer to non-European equivalents that do not conform to European models.}} {{cite journal |author= | last = Meyers | first = Dean | authorlink = |year= 1994 |title= Siam under siege (1893-1902): modern Thailand's decisive decade, from the Paknam incident to the first flowering of the Chakri reformation |journal= [[Journal of the Siam Society]] |format= PDF|volume= JSS Vol. 082.0k |issue= digital |page= image |pages= |nopp= |publisher= Siam Heritage Trust |doi= |url= http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/1991/JSS_082_0k_Meyers_SiamUnderSiege1893to1902.pdf|accessdate= 17 March 2013|quote= }} In 1905, 37 years after his coronation, Chulalongkorn ended [[slavery]] with the Slave Abolition Act. In 1867 slaves accounted for one-third of the Siamese population. His son, [[Vajiravudh]] (Rama VI), ascended to the throne in 1910 and continued his father's zeal for reform to bring the monarchy into the 20th century. The perceived slow pace of reform resulted in the [[Palace Revolt of 1912]]. In 1914, Vajiravudh determined that the act providing for invoking [[martial law#Thailand|martial law]], first promulgated by his father in 1907, was not consistent with modern [[laws of war]], nor convenient for the preservation of the security of the state, so it was amended to a more modern form that, with minor amendments, continued in force through subsequent changes in government.{{cite web|url= http://www.thailawforum.com/laws/Martial%20Law.pdf|title= Martial Law, B.E. 2457 (1914) — unofficial translation |accessdate= 21 May 2014|author= Pakorn Nilprapunt|year= 2006|format= PDF|work= |website= thailawforum.com|publisher= Office of the Council of State|quote= Reference to Thai legislation in any jurisdiction shall be to the Thai version only. This translation has been made so as to establish correct understanding about this Act to the foreigners.}} [[Prajadhipok]] (Rama VII) succeeded his brother in 1925. The [[Eton College|Eton]] and [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst|Sandhurst]] educated monarch created a council similar to a [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]], where the most important government officials could meet to decide state affairs. This advisory and legislative council, styled the [[Supreme Council of State of Siam]] (Thai: อภิรัฐมนตรีสภา) was founded on 28 November 1925 and existed until 1932. ===Constitutional monarchy=== [[File:Prajadhipok's coronation records - 001.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Prajadhipok|King Prajadhipok]] signing the [[Constitution of Thailand#1932 Constitution|Constitution of Siam]], 10 December 1932.]] In June 1932, a group of foreign-educated students and military men called "[[Khana Ratsadon|the promoters]]" carried out a bloodless [[Siamese Revolution of 1932|revolution]], seized power and demanded that King Prajadhipok grant the people of Siam a constitution. The king agreed and in December 1932 the people were granted [[Constitution of Thailand|a constitution]], ending 150 years of absolute Chakri rule. From then on the role of the monarch was relegated to that of a symbolic head of state. His powers from then on were exercised by a [[Prime Minister of Thailand|prime minister]] and the [[National Assembly of Thailand|national assembly]]. In 1935 King Pradhipok (Rama VII) abdicated the throne, following disagreements with the government. He lived in exile in the United Kingdom until his death in 1941. The king was replaced by his young nephew [[Ananda Mahidol]] (Rama VIII). The new king was 10 years old and was living abroad in [[Switzerland]]. A council of regents was appointed in his place. During this period the roles and powers of the king were entirely usurped by the [[Fascism|fascist]] government of [[Plaek Phibunsongkhram]], who changed the name of the kingdom from Siam to [[Thaification|Thailand]], and aligned it on the side of the [[Axis powers]] in the [[Pacific War|Pacific theatre of World War II]]. By the end of the war Phibunsongkhram was removed and the young king returned. The [[Free Thai]] movement provided resistance to foreign occupation during the war and helped rehabilitate Thailand after the war. After Rama VIII's sudden death from a bullet wound in 1946, Prince [[Bhumibol Adulyadej]] (Rama IX), aged 19 years old, became the new monarch. In establishing his rule, the king was aided by the efforts of the US government, who used the monarchy as a bulwark against communist gains in Southeast Asia.{{cite book|last1=Rattanasengchanh|first1=Phimmasone Michael|title=Thailand's Second Triumvirate: Sarit Thanarat and the military, King Bhumibol Adulyadej and the monarchy and the United States. 1957-1963| date=2012|publisher=University of Washington|location=Seattle|url=https://digital.lib.washington.edu/researchworks/bitstream/handle/1773/21997/Rattanasengchanh_washington_0250O_10615.pdf?sequence=1|accessdate=26 April 2017|format=MA Thesis}}{{RP|50}} King Bhumibol was the world's longest reigning monarch at the time of his death in October 2016. He died on 13 October 2016 at the age of 88.{{cite web|title=Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej dies at 88| url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/13/asia/thai-king-bhumibol-adulyadej-dies/|website=CNN|accessdate=13 October 2016}} === The monarchy in the 21st century=== [[File:Bhumibol Adulyadej and Sirikit 7 May 1950.jpg|thumb|upright|right|200px|King [[Bhumibol Adulyadej]] and Queen [[Sirikit]], granting a public audience on 7 May 1950. King Bhumibol was Thailand's longest reigning monarch (1946-2016).]] Since c. 2000, the role of the Thai monarchy has been increasingly challenged by scholars, media, observers and traditionalists, and as more educated pro-democracy interests began to express their speech.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} Many deemed that a series of laws and measures relating to [[lèse majesté in Thailand]] are hindrances to freedom of expression. Dozens of arrests, hundreds of criminal investigations and multiple imprisonments have been made based on these laws.{{cite web|title=Running Afoul of the Thai Monarchy| url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/09/18/world/asia/thailand-king-lese-majeste.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=22 September 2015}} King Bhumibol Adulyadej's speech in his 2005 national birthday broadcast could be interpreted that he [[Lèse majesté in Thailand#King invites criticism|welcomed criticism]].{{cite web|date=5 December 2005|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2005/12/05/headlines/data/headlines_19334288.html|title=Royal Birthday Address: 'King Can Do Wrong'|work=The Nation|accessdate=26 November 2016|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DAzbOJh9?url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2005/12/05/headlines/data/headlines_19334288.html|archivedate=25 December 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} The [[Lèse majesté in Thailand|lèse-majesté law]] is part of Thailand’s Criminal Code and has been described as "world's harshest lèse majesté law"{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-01-10/thai-king-requests-constitutional-changes-to-ensure-powers/8174062|title=New Thai King requests constitutional changes to 'ensure his royal powers': Prime Minister|author-first=Liam|author-last=Cochrane|date=2017-01-11|accessdate=2017-04-20|publisher=ABC|website=ABC News}} and "possibly the strictest criminal-defamation law anywhere".{{cite news|title=How powerful people use criminal-defamation laws to silence their critics|url=https://www.economist.com/news/international/21724993-some-countries-insulting-politicians-can-lead-jail-how-powerful-people-use|accessdate=14 July 2017|work=[[The Economist]]|date=13 July 2017}} Political scientist [[Giles Ungpakorn]] noted that "the ''lèse-majesté'' laws are not really designed to protect the institution of the monarchy. In the past, the laws have been used to protect governments and to shield military coups from lawful criticism. This whole [royal] image is created to bolster a conservative elite well beyond the walls of the palace."{{cite news |date=13 March 2007 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/03/13/wthai13.xml|title=Swiss man faces jail for lèse majesté|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=24 November 2007 }} The king is assisted in his work and duties by the Private Secretary to the King of Thailand and the [[Privy Council of Thailand]], in consultation with the head of the cabinet, the [[Prime Minister of Thailand|Prime Minister]]. In accordance with the constitution the king is no longer the originator of all laws in the kingdom; that prerogative is entrusted to the [[National Assembly of Thailand]]. All bills passed by the legislature, however, require his royal assent to become law. The monarchy's household and finances are managed by the [[Bureau of the Royal Household]] and the [[Crown Property Bureau]] respectively, these agencies are not considered part of the Thai government and all personnel are appointed by the king.{{cite web|url=http://www.photius.com/countries/thailand/government/thailand_government_the_king.html |title=Thailand The King – Flags, Maps, Economy, History, Climate, Natural Resources, Current Issues, International Agreements, Population, Social Statistics, Political System |publisher=Photius.com |date=28 December 1972 |accessdate=5 May 2012}} The junta which took power in 2014 has been aggressive in jailing critics of the monarchy. In 2015, it spent US$540 million, more than the budget of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, on a promotional campaign called "Worship, protect and uphold the monarchy." The campaign includes television commercials, seminars in schools and prisons, singing contests, and competitions to write stories and films praising the king. "This is not propaganda," [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]], the leader of the junta, said. "The youth must be educated on what the king has done."{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Thomas|title=With King in Declining Health, Future of Monarchy in Thailand Is Uncertain|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/21/world/with-king-in-declining-health-future-of-monarchy-in-thailand-is-uncertain.html?_r=1|accessdate=22 September 2015|work=The New York Times|date=2015-09-20}} In its fiscal year 2016 budget, the ruling military government has increased its expenditure for "upholding, protecting and preserving the monarchy" to 18 billion baht (US$514 million), an increase of 28 percent for this budget line item since 2014 when it took power.{{cite news|title=For Thailand, a portrait is crucial to preparations for succession|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/for-thailand-a-portrait-is-crucial-to-preparations-for-succession|accessdate=27 April 2016|work=Straits Times|date=2016-04-21}} ===Timeline of monarchs=== {{Main article|List of monarchs of Thailand|Thai monarchs' family tree}} {{See also|List of Thai royal consorts}} ImageSize = width:1200 height:auto barincrement:12 PlotArea = top:10 1935 color:c text:"[[Prajadhipok|Rama VII]]" from:1935 till: 1946 color:c text:"[[Ananda Mahidol|Rama VIII]]" from:1946 till: 2016 color:c text:"[[Bhumibol Adulyadej|Rama IX]]" from:2016 till: 2018 color:c text:"[[Vajiralongkorn|Rama X]]" barset:skip ==Royal regalia== {{main|Coronation of the Thai monarch}} [[File:Royal Regalia of Siam.jpg|thumb|upright|right|The royal regalia of Thailand is made up of five principal items.]] The present set of [[royal regalia of Thailand]] (Khrueang Raja Kakudhabhand, {{lang-th|เครื่องราชกกุธภัณฑ์)}} and the royal utensils was created mostly during the reign of King Rama I and Rama IV, after the previous set was lost during the sack of Ayutthaya by the Burmese in 1767. The regalia is used mainly during the [[coronation]] ceremony of the king at the beginning of every reign. The regalia is presently on display in the Museum of the [[Grand Palace]] in Bangkok.{{cite web|url=http://geocities.com/threeb.rm/regalia.html |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=27 October 2009 |accessdate=5 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027073704/http://geocities.com/threeb.rm/regalia.html |archivedate=27 October 2009 }}Thai Government Public Relations: [http://thailand.prd.go.th/60th/royal_utensil.php?PHPSESSID=bbd4c7793853bd5ce0fdc2a51109a0e6 Royal Regalia + Royal Utensils.] * [[Royal Nine-Tiered Umbrella]] (Phra Maha Swetachatra; พระมหาเศวตฉัตร)- the most important regalia. Currently there are seven, distributed at various palaces. * [[Great Crown of Victory]] (Phra Maha Phijay Mongkut; พระมหาพิชัยมงกุฎ)- official headgear. * [[Sword of Victory]] (Phra Saengkharga Jay Sri; พระแสงขรรค์ชัยศรี)- found at [[Tonlé Sap]] in 1784, the sword represents military power. * [[Royal Staff]] (Dharn Phra Korn; ธารพระกร)- symbol of justice * Royal Fan and Flywhisk (Walawijani; วาลวีชนี)- Royal fan made of gold and the royal flywhisk made from the tail of a [[white elephant]]. * Royal Slippers (Chalong Phra Bada; ฉลองพระบาท)- official footwear made of gold The Thai royal utensils (Phra Khattiya Rajuprapoke; พระขัตติยราชูปโภค) are also for the personal use of the monarch, comprising: * the [[Betel nut]] set * the water urn * the libation vessel * the receptacle. These unique objects are always placed on either side of the king's throne or his seat during royal ceremonies. ===Other symbols of kingship=== *[[White Elephant|Royal White Elephant]]- usually one to represent each reign, the current one resides at [[Dusit Zoo]]; the king also has 10 others. *[[Emblem of Thailand|Royal Garuda]]- Emblem of the king and of Thailand *[[Royal Standard of Thailand]]- Official standard of the king *[[Royal Flags of Thailand|Royal Flags]]- Personal flags of the king and royal family *[[Sansoen Phra Barami]] - The royal anthem *[[Prakhom band|Traditional Band of the Royal Family of Thailand]] - [[Marching band]] using traditional Thai musical instruments, they usually accompany the royal family and perform at ceremonies where a member of the royal family presides. ==Royal ceremonies== [[File:Vladimir Putin at APEC Summit in Thailand 19-21 October 2003-12.jpg|thumb|right|280px|The Royal Barge Procession, 2003.]] The and other members of his family carry out many royal ceremonies per year, some dating from the 13th century. *[[coronation of the Thai monarch|Royal coronation ceremony]] *[[Royal Barge Procession]] *[[Royal Ploughing Ceremony]] *[[The Changing of the Robes of the Emerald Buddha]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pattayamail.com/457/news.shtml |title=Kingdom of Thailand celebrates Wan Chatramongkhol (Coronation Day) May 5 |work=Pattaya Mail |accessdate=5 May 2012}} *[[Thai Royal Guards parade|Trooping the Colours and Armed Forces Pledge of Loyalty]] *Military Colours Consecration and Pledge Taking Ceremony *Oath of Allegiance Ceremony *[[Speech from the Throne]] to the [[National Assembly of Thailand]] *[[Thai royal funeral|Royal Funeral Ceremony]] ==Royal orders and decorations== {{References|section|date= November 2017}} {{See also|List of orders and medals of Thailand}} king is sovereign of several [[Order (decoration)|Royal Orders and Decorations]], the prerogative to appoint and remove any persons from these orders are at the king's discretion. However, sometimes recommendations are made by the [[Cabinet of Thailand]] and the [[Prime Minister of Thailand|Prime Minister]]. There are twelve Royal Orders and some of these have separate classes. *The Most Auspicious [[Order of the Rajamitrabhorn]]: Established on 11 June 1962 by King Rama IX to be bestowed upon foreign heads of state. *The Most Illustrious [[Order of the Royal House of Chakri]]: Established in 1882 by King Rama V of the Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand) to commemorate the Bangkok Centennial. *The Ancient and Auspicious [[Order of the Nine Gems]]: Established in 1851 by King Rama IV of the Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand). The order is bestowed upon the members of the Thai royal family and distinguished high-ranking officials who have given service to the kingdom and who are Buddhist. *The Most Illustrious [[Order of Chula Chom Klao]]: Established on 16 November 1873 by King Rama V of The Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand) to commemorate the 90th Jubilee of the Chakri Dynasty, and bears his name. *The [[Ratana Varabhorn Order of Merit]]: Established on 1 August 1911 by King Rama VI of The Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand) to reward personal service to the sovereign. *The Honourable [[Order of Rama]]: Established on 22 July 1918 (B.E. 2461) by King Rama VI of the Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand), to be bestowed onto those who have rendered special military services either in peace or in wartime. *The Most Exalted [[Order of the White Elephant]]: Established in 1861 by King Rama IV of the Kingdom of Siam. Along with the Order of the Crown of Thailand, it is regularly awarded to government officials for each five years of service, making it Thailand's most-awarded order. *The Most Noble [[Order of the Crown of Thailand]]: Established in 1869 by King Rama V of The Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand) for Thais, the royal family, governmental employees, and foreign dignitaries for their outstanding services to the Kingdom of Thailand. *The Most Admirable [[Order of the Direkgunabhorn]]: Established by King Rama IX on 22 July 1991 (B.E.2534) to be bestowed upon those who have rendered devotional services to the Kingdom of Thailand. *The [[Vallabhabhorn Order]]: Established on 22 March 1919 (B.E. 2461) by King Rama VI of The Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand).{{More info}} *The [[Order of Ramkeerati]]: Established on 26 November 1987 (B.E. 2530) by King Rama IX of Thailand to be bestowed onto those who have rendered constant service and support to Boy Scout activities for at least five consecutive years. *The [[Vajira Mala Order]]: Established on 28 May 1911 (B.E. 2454) by King Rama VI of the Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand).{{More info}} ==See also== * [[Sacred king]] * [[Lèse majesté in Thailand]] *[[List of honours of Thailand awarded to heads of state and royalty]] *[[List of honours of the Thai Royal Family by country]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin}} * The Constitution of the Kingdom of Thailand (2007), [[s:2007 Constitution of Thailand]] * Aryan, Gothan (15 – 16 September 2004), [https://web.archive.org/web/20060623005429/http://www.idea.int/news/upload/Nepal%20-%20Thai%20monarchy%20paper%20-%20Gothom%20Aryan.pdf Thai Monarchy], International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance, Retrieved on 5 July 2006, presented in Kathmandu, Nepal * Kullada Kesboonchoo Mead, The Rise and Decline of Thai Absolutism, RoutledgeCurzon 2004 {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Monarchs of Thailand}} ; Website * [http://www.kanchanapisek.or.th/ Website of the King's 50 Anniversary Celebration] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090201152646/http://mahidol.ac.th/thailand/chakri.html The illustrious Chakri family] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081224022152/http://www.soravij.com/rama9.html The Royal Family, History and Information] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080926091434/http://sunsite.au.ac.th/thailand/thai_monarchy/background.html Website on the Thai Monarchy] ; E-books * {{cite book | author = [[Thanin Kraivichien]] | location = Bangkok | language = Thai | publisher = Department of Academic Affairs, Ministry of Education | title = Thai King under Democratic System | year = 1976 | format = pdf | url = http://dl.parliament.go.th/bitstream/handle/lirt/338053/2519_%E0%B8%9E%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A9%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%95%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B9%8C%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2_%E0%B8%98%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A3%E0%B9%8C_%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%A0.pdf?sequence=1 }} * {{cite book | author = Yut Saeng-uthai | location = Bangkok | language = Thai | publisher = Winyuchon | title = A Legal Treatise on the Provisions of the Constitution governing the King | year = 2008 | isbn = 9789742886332 | format = pdf | url = http://dl.parliament.go.th/bitstream/handle/lirt/301326/56515.pdf?sequence=1 }} {{Monarchies}} {{Monarchs of Thailand}} {{Government of Thailand}} {{Southeast Asian leaders}} [[Category:Thai monarchy| ]] [[Category:History of Thailand]] [[Category:Monarchies of Asia|Thailand]] [[Category:Southeast Asian monarchs]] [[Category:Thai royalty| ]]
