{{Distinguish|Albanian National Reconciliation Party}}{{Infobox political party | name = National Reconciliation Party | native_name = | logo = | colorcode = #0073CF | leader = [[Hamat Bah]] | chairman = | chairperson = | president = | secretary_general = | spokesperson = | founder = 1997 | leader1_title = | leader1_name = | slogan = | founded = | dissolved = | merger = | split = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | headquarters = | newspaper = | paramilitary_wing = | student_wing = | youth_wing = | wing1_title = | wing1 = | membership_year = | membership = | religion = | national = | international = | affiliation1_title = | affiliation1 = | ideology = [[Reconciliation theology|Reconciliation]]
[[Constitutionalism]] | colors = | blank1_title = | blank1 = | seats1_title = [[National Assembly of the Gambia|National Assembly]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|{{GmbNA|NRP}}|58|hex=#0073CF}} | symbol = | flag = | website = | country = Gambia | footnotes = }} The '''National Reconciliation Party''' is a political party in [[The Gambia]]. It was founded in 1996, and is led by its founder, [[Hamat Bah]]. == History == The National Reconciliation Party was founded in 1996 by [[Hamat Bah]] as part of his intention to run for the presidency. He finished third in the 1996 presidential election. 2 NRP NAMs were elected in the 1997 parliamentary election. In the 2001 presidential election, Bah came third. The NRP was part of the [[Coalition 2016]] for the [[Gambian presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], where [[Adama Barrow]] was declared the coalition's candidate and subsequently won.{{cite news|url=http://gainako.com/gambian-opposition-parties-set-select-single-candidate-december-polls-convention/ |title=Gambian Opposition Parties Set to Select a Single Candidate for December polls at a Convention |website=GAINAKO |date=30 October 2016}} == Electoral results == The parties [[elections in Gambia|electoral results]] have been: * won 2 of the 48 seats in the [[Gambian parliamentary election, 1997|1997 parliamentary elections]] * won 1 of the 48 seats in the [[Gambian parliamentary election, 2002|2002 parliamentary elections]] * won none of the 48 seats in the [[Gambian parliamentary election, 2007|2007 parliamentary elections]] * won 1 of the 48 seats in the [[Gambian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary elections]] (plus 1 seat in a mid-term election) * won 4 of the 53 seats in the [[Gambian parliamentary election, 2017|2017 parliamentary elections]] == Notable members == * [[Hamat Bah]], Leader of the NRP (1996–present), NAM (1997–2005), [[Minister of Tourism and Culture (The Gambia)|Minister of Tourism and Culture]] (2017–present) * [[Modou Bamba Gaye]], NAM (2015–2017) * [[Samba Jallow]], NAM (2012–present), National Assembly Minority Leader (2012–present) == References == {{Reflist}} {{Gambian political parties}} [[Category:Political parties in the Gambia]] [[Category:National Reconciliation Party politicians|*Main]] {{Gambia-party-stub}}

Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{double image|right|Flag of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.svg|183|New-TRNC-coa.GIF|115|The [[Flag of Northern Cyprus]]|The [[Coat of arms of Northern Cyprus]]}} [[Image:LocationNorthernCyprus.png|thumb|The location of [[Northern Cyprus]]]] [[Image:Trnc-map.gif|thumb|An enlargeable map of [[Northern Cyprus]]]] [[Image:Cyprus districts named.png|thumb|An enlargeable political map of the island of [[Cyprus]]]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Northern Cyprus:
'''[[Northern Cyprus]]''' – [[de facto]] independent republic<ref name=HISTORY>Antiwar.com. [http://antiwar.com/hadar/?articleid=8042 In Praise of 'Virtual States'], Leon Hadar, November 16, 2005</ref><ref name=defacto1>Carter Johnson, University of Maryland. [http://www.bsos.umd.edu/gvpt/davenport/dcawcp/paper/DCAWCP_CJohnson_Partition.pdf Sovereignty or Demography? Reconsidering the Evidence on Partition in Ethnic Civil Wars] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626134359/http://www.bsos.umd.edu/gvpt/davenport/dcawcp/paper/DCAWCP_CJohnson_Partition.pdf |date=2008-06-26 }}, 2005</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Emerson|first= Michael|title= The Wider Europe Matrix|year= 2004|publisher= CPSE|isbn=92-9079-469-0}}</ref> on the Mediterranean island of [[Cyprus]]. Officially it is the northern territory of the [[Republic of Cyprus]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 2, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cy.html|title=Cyprus|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> The territory includes the [[Kokkina exclave]], a [[enclave and exclave|pene-enclave]] "of" the rest of Cyprus, partly surrounded by sea.
The TRNC declared independence in 1983, nine years after a Greek Cypriot [[coup d'état|coup]] attempting to annex the island to Greece triggered [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus|an invasion]] by [[Turkey]]. It has received [[Embassy of Turkey in the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus|diplomatic recognition]] only from Turkey, on which it is dependent for economic, political and military support. The rest of the international community, including the United Nations and European Union, recognises the sovereignty of the [[Cyprus|Republic of Cyprus]] over the whole island.

{{Infobox scientist | name = Paul De Grauwe | image = Paul De Grauwe.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1946|7|18}} | birth_place = [[Ukkel]], [[Belgium]] | nationality = Belgian | residence = | citizenship = | fields = [[International economics]], [[Monetary economics]], [[European economy]] | workplaces = [[London School of Economics]], [[KU Leuven]] | alma_mater = [[Johns Hopkins University]], [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] | thesis_title = The interaction of monetary policies in a group of European countries.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/search?qt=worldcat_org_all&q=Paul+De+Grauwe#x0%253Abook%2Bx4%253Athsisformat WorldCat], Retrieved 15 January 2013.</ref> | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1973 | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = Prize of the European Communities (1976), Amex Bank Review Award (1990), [[Arkprijs van het Vrije Woord|Ark Prize of Free Speech]]<ref name="Paul De Grauwe Arkprijs"/> (2013) | religion = | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Paul De Grauwe''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈpʌul də ˈɣrʌuə}}; born 18 July 1946) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[economics|economist]] and [[John Paulson]] Professor in European Political Economy at the [[London School of Economics and Political Science]] as head of the European Institute. He is also [[professor emeritus]] in [[international economics]] at [[KU Leuven]] and former member of the [[Belgian Federal Parliament]].
== Education and career ==
De Grauwe studied [[economics]] at the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] from 1964 until 1969. Having received a scholarship from the [[Fulbright Commission Belgium|Belgian Fulbright Commission]], De Grauwe obtained his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD degree]] at [[Johns Hopkins University]] in 1973. He started to work as an intern at the [[European Economic Community]] in 1969 and later went on to become a research assistant, and subsequently a professor at the Center for Economic Studies of the Katholieke Universiteit Leuven.
In 1973 De Grauwe began to work as an economist at the [[International Monetary Fund]] and accepted positions at the [[Centre for European Policy Studies]]<ref>[http://www.ceps.eu/member/paul-de-grauwe Member CEPS], CEPS - The Centre for European Policy Studies, Retrieved January 16, 2013.</ref> and the [[European Central Bank]]. He has also been professor at the [[College of Europe]], the [[Free University of Berlin]], and the [[Norwegian School of Management]]. Furthermore, he has been a [[visiting scholar]] at the [[University of Michigan]], [[Tilburg University]], the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]], [[University of Kiel]], [[Bank of Japan]], [[Université libre de Bruxelles]], [[University of Saarbrücken]], [[Ghent University]], the [[Catholic University of Portugal]], the [[Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System]], [[University of Amsterdam]], [[Humboldt University of Berlin]], and [[Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore]]. In addition, De Grauwe has been given doctoral [[honorary degree]]s at the [[University of St Gallen]], the [[university of Valencia]], the [[Turku School of Economics|Turku School of Economics and Business Administration]] and the [[University of Genoa]].<ref name="CV Paul De Grauwe">[http://www.econ.kuleuven.be/ew/academic/intecon/Degrauwe/CV-PDG-2008.pdf Curriculum Vitae: Paul De Grauwe], Faculty of Economics - KU Leuven, Retrieved 15 January 2013.</ref><ref name="Paul De Grauwe LSE">[http://www2.lse.ac.uk/europeanInstitute/staff/academicStaff/DeGrauwe/Home.aspx Academic staff - Paul De Grauwe], London School of Economics and Political Science, Retrieved 15 January 2013.</ref>
During 1991-1995 and 1999-2003, Paul De Grauwe was a member of the [[Senate (Belgium)|Belgian Senate]], and from 1995 until 1999 he became a member of parliament in the [[Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Belgian Chamber of Representatives]]. In both houses of parliament he was part of the [[Flemish Liberals and Democrats]].<ref name="CV Paul De Grauwe"/><ref>[http://www.senate.be/www/?MIval=/showSenator&ID=39&LANG=nl Paul De Grauwe - VLD], Senate of the Belgian Kingdom, Retrieved January 16, 2013.</ref>
He is editor of various economic [[academic journals]] and a former member of the Group of Economic Policy Analysis advising the [[European Commission]] President [[José Manuel Barroso]],<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/policy_advisers/experts_groups/gepa_en.htm Group of Economic Policy Analysis (GEPA)], Bureau of European Policy Advisers (BEPA), Retrieved January 16, 2013.</ref> as well as director of the money, macro and international finance research network of CESifo at the [[University of Munich]].<ref name="Paul De Grauwe LSE"/> He has had a column in the [[Financial Times]]. Belgian media often make use of his expertise when dealing with current economic affairs, primarily with regard to European economic and monetary issues. Besides hundreds of scientific articles, he has published various books as well. Furthermore, he is co-editor and author of economic textbooks in both Dutch and English. He is the author of ''The Economics of Monetary Union'', which was translated in ten languages.<ref name="Paul De Grauwe LSE"/> From December 2011 until May 2012, De Grauwe served as member of the [[Jacques Delors Institute]]’s Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa group, a high-level expert group to reflect on the reform of the [[Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union]].<ref>[http://www.delorsinstitute.eu/011-3024-Tommaso-Padoa-Schioppa-Group.html Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa Group] [[Jacques Delors Institute]].</ref>
In 2012, De Grauwe reached the [[retirement age|legal age]] for [[mandatory retirement]] in Belgium, after which he was offered the [[John Paulson]] Chair in European Political Economy at the [[London School of Economics and Political Science]] and retired from his position at the University of Leuven. He has expressed his discontent with the legal retirement age: ''I felt disparaged, like an old machine in a factory. Our [Belgian] legislation says: "you have become economically worthless," but I also felt struck in my identity as a person. You have to give people the freedom of choice if they want to continue working after their 65th [birthday], end of story. I understand those who feel exhausted and quit, but I wanted to continue functioning academically and this wasn't an option here [in Belgium].''<ref>{{nl}} [http://www.vacature.com/blog/paul-de-grauwe-65-afgeschreven-in-belgi-topper-in-londen Paul De Grauwe (65): Afgeschreven in België, topper in Londen], Vacature.com, Published on 22 June 2012. Retrieved May 10, 2013.</ref><ref>{{nl}} [http://www.veto.be/jg38/veto3807/navraag-paul-de-grauwe Navraag Paul De Grauwe - Economie is moeilijker dan fysica] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518093153/http://www.veto.be/jg38/veto3807/navraag-paul-de-grauwe |date=2015-05-18 }}, Veto, Retrieved May 10, 2013.</ref>
==Recognition== In May 2013, De Grauwe was awarded the [[Arkprijs van het Vrije Woord]] (Ark Prize of Free Speech).<ref name="Paul De Grauwe Arkprijs">{{nl}} [http://www.standaard.be/cnt/DMF20130327_00519771 Paul De Grauwe wint Arkprijs van het Vrije Woord], De Standaard, Retrieved May 9, 2013.</ref>
== Market ideology ==
As a [[liberalism|liberal]] and advocate of the [[free market]] De Grauwe has long time been a strong proponent of the [[market economy]] and [[globalisation]]. In ''De onvoltooide globalisering'' (''The Uncompleted Globalisation''), written for a broader audience, he explains why he favors globalisation and discusses the statements of [[anti-globalization movement|anti-globalists]], which he finds somewhat pessimistic. He sees himself as an optimist and believes that market forces and economic growth will offer a solution to the issues related to natural resources, energy, environment and climate. However, De Grauwe has recently pointed out the necessity of government in this market economy. He said he used to uphold financial markets as bearers of the truth but now acknowledges that it is a world where rationality is intertwined with emotions. In an interview, he stated that certain entities are needed to correct market forces. Because of the [[Great Recession|global financial crisis]], the need to correct the market is greater today than before. For this reason his acknowledgement of a strong government has increased.<ref>{{nl}} [http://www.econ.kuleuven.be/eng/ew/Articles%20press/2011/PDG_De%20Morgen_221011_p42.pdf 'Was ik 25, dan stond ik nu op Wall Street mee te betogen'], Faculty of Economics - KU Leuven, Retrieved 15 January 2013.</ref><ref>{{nl}} [http://www.demorgen.be/dm/nl/3324/Financiele-crisis/article/detail/1350346/2011/11/18/Paul-De-Grauwe-geeft-foute-ideeen-over-financiele-markten-toe.dhtml Paul De Grauwe geeft foute ideeën over financiële markten toe], De Morgen, Retrieved January 16, 2013.</ref>
== Selected publications == * "The limits of markets", Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2017. * "Economics of Monetary Union" (Ed.), Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2012. * "Animal spirits and monetary policy", ''Economic Theory'', vol. 47, no. 2, 2011, pp. 423 – 442. * "The Return of Keynes", ''International Finance'', vol. 13, no. 1, 2010, pp. 157 – 163. * "The Fragility of the Eurozone’s Institutions", ''Open Economies Review'', vol. 21, no. 1, 2010, pp. 167 – 174. * "What have we learnt about monetary integration since the Maastricht Treaty?", ''Journal of Common Market Studies'', vol. 44, no. 4, 2006, pp. 711 – 730. * "Prospects for monetary unions after the Euro", Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 2005.
'''With others''' * De Grauwe, P, & Ji, Y. (2013). "Panic-driven austerity in the Eurozone and its implications", ''Vox EU'', [http://www.voxeu.org/article/panic-driven-austerity-eurozone-and-its-implications Paper on voxeu.org], 21 February 2013. * De Grauwe, P., & Kaltwasser, P. R. (2012). "The Exchange Rate in Behavioral Framework". In James, J., Marsh, I., & Sarno, L. (Eds.) ''The Handbook of Exchange Rates'', Wiley. * Altavilla C., & De Grauwe, P. (2010). "Non-Linearities in the Relation Between the Exchange Rate and the Fundamentals", ''International Research Journal of Finance and Economics'', vol. 15, pp. 1 – 21. * De Grauwe, P., Moesen, W. (2009). "Gains for all: a proposal for a common euro bond", ''Intereconomics'', vol. 33, no. 3, pp. 132 – 141. * De Grauwe, P., & Senegas, M. (2006). "Monetary policy design and transmission asymmetry in EMU: Does uncertainty matter?", ''European journal of political economy'', vol. 22, no. 4, pp. 787 – 808. * De Grauwe, P., & Zhang, Z. (2006). "Introduction: Monetary and economic integration in the East Asian region", ''World economy'', vol. 29, no. 12, pp. 1643 – 1647. * Aksoy, Y., De Grauwe, P., & Dewachter, H. (2002). "Do asymmetries matter for European monetary policy?", ''European Economic Review'', vol. 46, no. 3, pp. 443 – 469.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2008}} {{Infobox Political Party |name = Reform Party |logo = |leader = Lyana Armstrong-Emery |foundation = 21 March 2000 |dissolved =2005 |ideology = [[Green politics]]
[[Eco-socialism]] |position = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] |international = |european = [[Green Party of England and Wales]]
[[Mebyon Kernow]] |europarl = |colours = Green |headquarters = |website = |country=Gibraltar|colorcode=Green}} {{Politics of Gibraltar}} The '''Gibraltar Reform Party''' was a political party in [[Gibraltar]]. It was a [[left-wing politics|left]]-leaning party which described itself as [[green movement|green]] and for [[social justice]]. Originally formed as the '''Independent Liberal Forum''' on 21 March 2000, the name was subsequently changed to the later one. The last party leader was Lyana Armstrong-Emery. The party's broad aim was a decentralisation of power. On the [[Disputed status of Gibraltar|constitutional status of Gibraltar]], the party supported a new status, calling for Gibraltar's establishment as a devolved autonomous territory, integrated within a decentralised [[federation|federal]] Britain. The party also called for the creation of a local [[Gibraltar Parliament|Parliament for Gibraltar]], a Member of Parliament (MP) to sit in the [[British House of Commons]] in [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Westminster]], and a [[Member of the European Parliament]] (MEP) to represent Gibraltar in the [[European Parliament]]. The Reform Party forged links with both the [[Green Party of England and Wales]] and [[Mebyon Kernow]]. Lyana Armstrong-Emery was voted by the party to take the position on the joint list agreed with the Green Party for the European Elections. The party ceased operations in 2005 owing to a failure to garner wide public support. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070906165112/http://www.gibnet.gi/~emery/ Former ILF Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20030921051712/http://www.reformpartygib.com:80/ Former Reform Party Website] {{Gibraltar political parties}} {{Gibraltar topics}} [[Category:Defunct political parties in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2000]] [[Category:2000 establishments in Gibraltar]] {{Gibraltar-party-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Archdiocese | name = Huê | latin = Archidioecesis Hueensis | local = Tổng Giáo Phận Huế | image = Phu Cam2.JPG | image_size = 230px | image_alt = | caption = Cathedral of Huê | coat = | coat_size = | coat_alt = | flag = | flag_size = | flag_alt = | country = {{flag|Vietnam}} | territory = | province = Huê | metropolitan = | archdeaconries = | deaneries = | subdivisions = | coordinates = | area_km2 = 12,227 | area_sqmi = | area_footnotes = | population = 2,150,700 | population_as_of = 2006 | catholics = 66,700 | catholics_percent = 3.1 | parishes = | churches = | congregations = | schools = | members = | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | sui_iuris_church = [[Latin Church]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | established = 1960 | cathedral = Cathedral of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in [[Huế]] | cocathedral = | patron = | patron_title = | priests = | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} | patriarch = | major_archbishop = | bishop = | bishop_title = | metro_archbishop = [[Joseph Nguyễn Chí Linh]] | coadjutor = | suffragans = | auxiliary_bishops = | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = | emeritus_bishops = [[Francis Xavier Lê Văn Hồng]] Archbishop Emeritus (2012-2016)
Stephen Nguyễn Như Thể Archbishop Emeritus (1998–2012) | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | website = {{URL|http://tonggiaophanhue.net/}} | footnotes = }} '''''Archdiocese (Metropolitan) of Huế''''' ({{lang-la|Archidioecesis Huéensis}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] Archdiocese in central [[Vietnam]]. The creation of the diocese in its present form was declared on 24 November 1960. It covers an area of 12,227 km² and headed by [[Archbishop]] [[Joseph Nguyễn Chí Linh]] (from 2016), who was previously the Bishop of [[Thanh Hóa]]. The suffragan dioceses are: * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Ban Mê Thuôt|Diocese of Ban Mê Thuôt]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Đà Nẵng|Diocese of Đà Nẵng]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Kontum|Diocese of Kontum]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Nha Trang|Diocese of Nha Trang]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Quy Nhơn|Diocese of Quy Nhơn]]. Immaculate Heart of Mary Cathedral in [[Huế]] has been assigned as the Cathedral of the [[Archdiocese]].[http://www.gcatholic.org/churches/data/cathVN.htm#chk GCatholic.org] By 2004, the Archdiocese of Huế had about 65,770 Roman Catholics (3.3% of the population), 93 priests and 177 parishes.[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dhuev.html Catholic Hierarchy Directory profile of the Archdiocese of Huế] ==Ordinaries== *François Pellerin, [[Paris Foreign Missions Society|MEP]], 1850–62 *Joseph Sohier, MEP, 1862–76 *Jean Pontvianne, MEP, 1877–79 *Louis Caspar, MEP, 1880–1907 *Eugène Allys, MEP, 1908-1931 *Alexandre Chabanon, MEP, 1931–36 *François Lemasle, MEP, 1936–46 *[[Jean-Baptiste Urrutia]], MEP, 1948–60 *[[Pierre Martin Ngô Đình Thục]], 1960–68 *Philippe Nguyên-Kim-Diên, 1968–88 *Vacant (1988–98) *Stephen (Étienne) Nguyễn Như Thể, 1998–2012 *Francis Xavier Lê Văn Hồng, 2012–2016 *[[Joseph Nguyễn Chí Linh]], 2016–present ==References== ==External links== * {{Official website|http://tonggiaophanhue.net/}} {{vi icon}} {{Dioceses in Vietnam}} {{coord|16.4667|N|107.5830|E|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:VN|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hue}} [[Category:Huế]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Vietnam]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1960]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]] [[Category:Roman Catholic ecclesiastical provinces in Vietnam]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Ecclesiastical Province of Hue| ]] [[Category:1960 establishments in South Vietnam]] {{Vietnam-RC-diocese-stub}}

page.title: Slovakia in the Eurovision Song Contest 1993

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox song contest national year | Year = 1993 | Country = Slovakia | Preselection = Internal selection | Preselection date = | Entrant = [[Elán (band)|Elán]] | Song = Amnestia na neveru | Final result = ''Failed to qualify
from pre-selection'' }} '''Slovakia''' first attempted to enter the '''Eurovision Song Contest in 1993''' in [[Millstreet]], [[Ireland]], but were unsuccessful in qualifying. Slovak broadcaster [[Slovenská televízia|Slovenská Televízia]] (STV) selected Slovak band [[Elán (band)|Elán]] to represent the country for the first time in [[Eurovision Song Contest]] history. The song that represented Slovakia in [[Kvalifikacija za Millstreet]] was "Amnestia na neveru" ("Amnesty to infidelity"). == At Kvalifikacija za Millstreet == {{main|Kvalifikacija za Millstreet}} With the dissolution of the [[Soviet Union]] and the disintegration of Yugoslavia many newly independent countries were formed who became interested in competing in the Eurovision Song Contest. With this large influx of countries the European Broadcasting Union were forced to create a new measure to counter overcrowding in the contest. For the 1993 Contest the EBU decided to hold a one-off countest to select three countries to join the 22 countries already competing in the Eurovision Song Contest. The independently recognised countries of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Eurovision Song Contest|Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Croatia in the Eurovision Song Contest|Croatia]], [[Estonia in the Eurovision Song Contest|Estonia]], [[Hungary in the Eurovision Song Contest|Hungary]], [[Romania in the Eurovision Song Contest|Romania]], [[Slovakia in the Eurovision Song Contest|Slovakia]], and [[Slovenia in the Eurovision Song Contest|Slovenia]], took part at the Kvalifikacija za Millstreet which was held at the [[Radiotelevizija Slovenija|RTV SLO]] Broadcasting Centre in [[Ljubljana]], Slovenia on 3 April 1993. Slovakia performed 7th in the running order, following Slovenia. Elán received 50 points for their song and performance, placing 4th, thereby failing to qualify.{{cite web|title=About the show|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=235#About the show|work=Eurovision Song Contest 1993|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=18 September 2012|date=16 May 1993}} ==See also== *[[Slovakia in the Eurovision Song Contest]] *[[Eurovision Song Contest 1993]] *[[Kvalifikacija za Millstreet]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Slovakia in Eurovision}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1993}} [[Category:Countries in the Eurovision Song Contest 1993]] [[Category:Slovakia in the Eurovision Song Contest]] [[Category:1993 in Slovak music]] {{Slovakia-stub}}

'''Stefania Follini''' (born 16 August 1961) is an Italian [[interior design]]er. She is known for being involved in a 1989 experiment on [[circadian rhythm]]s, in which she voluntarily isolated herself for four months in an underground room thirty feet down a [[cave]] in [[Carlsbad, New Mexico]], away from all outside indications of night and day.<ref name="New York 1">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/24/us/after-130-days-of-cave-life-a-return-to-glare-of-the-sun.html |title=After 130 Days of Cave Life, A Return to Glare of the Sun |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 24, 1989 }}</ref> The experiment lasted from January 13, 1989, till May 22, 1989. In total, Follini spent some 130 days in the cave, thus breaking the women's world record for longest cave isolation.
==Career== Hailing from [[Ancona]], Italy, Follini worked as an interior decorator. Out of 20 candidates, Follini was chosen for the experiment because she possessed an "introspective nature" and "mental discipline".<ref name="Chicago 1"/> At that time, she was 27 years old.<ref name="Chicago 1"/>
===The experiment=== The scientific experiment commenced on January 13, 1989.<ref name="Chicago 1">{{cite news|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-05-24/news/8902030743_1_maurizio-montalbini-researchers-stefania-follini |title=No Light, Voices For 131 Days, But The Mice Were Friendly |last=Weingartem |first=Paul |date=May 24, 1989 }}</ref> It was organised by Pioneer Frontier Explorations<ref name="Time 1">{{cite news|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |title=The Times of Your Life |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,151968,00.html |date=June 24, 2001 |first=Anastasia |last=Toufexis }}</ref> and [[NASA]].<ref name="AP 1"/> It took place in the "Lost Cave" in New Mexico.<ref name="Horrible 1"/> Inside her twenty by twelve foot [[acrylic glass]] room, away from all cues to the normal 24-hour daily cycle, her biological clock drifted away from its regular rhythm to following first a 28-hour day,<ref name="Horrible 1"/> and later on a 48-hour one.<ref name="Time 1"/> She started staying awake for up to more than twenty hours and sleeping up to ten hours at a time. Her only companions were her guitar,<ref>{{cite news|date=May 16, 1989 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-05-16/news/mn-406_1_computer-messages-space-travelers-stefania-follini |newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |title=No Outside Link : Time Flies for Isolation Researcher }}</ref> a computer, two "friendly mice"<ref name="New York 1"/> named Giuseppe and Nicoletta,<ref name="AP 1"/> a few frogs,<ref name="Horrible 1"/> and grasshoppers.<ref name="Philly 1"/> During the course of the experiment, she was reported to have felt gloomy, with no human to cheer her up.<ref name="Horrible 1">{{cite book|title=Horrible Science: The Terrible Truth About Time |first=Nick |last=Arnold |publisher=[[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]] |page=28 |year=2009 }}</ref> Her only mode of communication was via the computer terminals.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/17/us/isolation-researcher-loses-track-of-time-in-cave.html |title=Isolation Researcher Loses Track of Time in Cave |date=May 17, 1989 }}</ref> To curb her boredom, Follini would decorate the cave with cutouts made from cardboard.<ref name="Philly 1">{{cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/1989-05-24/news/26113679_1_maurizio-montalbini-stefania-follini-experiment |newspaper=[[Philly.com]] |title=Woman Emerges After 130 Days Alone In A Cave |date=May 24, 1989 }}</ref>
With her slowed-down daily cycle, her meals were more spread out and she lost {{convert|17|lb|kg|}} in weight.<ref name="Philly 1"/> Follini was most of the time fed beans and rice, which partially resulted in her losing [[Vitamin D]].<ref name="AP 1">{{cite news|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1989/After-130-Days-in-a-Cave-Italian-Woman-Says-She-d-Return/id-40a98ef59e0ead5b4f6a17a534583d22 |title=AFTER 130 DAYS IN A CAVE, ITALIAN WOMAN SAYS SHE'D RETURN |last=Allen |first=Caroline |newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |date=June 7, 1989 }}</ref> She reported that at one point her [[menstrual cycle]] had stopped. She regularly did [[judo]] to maintain her strength and flexibility.<ref name="New York 1"/> When she finally emerged from the cave at the experiment's end in May 22, 1989,<ref name="People 1"/> and was asked to guess the date, she estimated that it was March 14<ref name="People 1">{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20120512,00.html |newspaper=[[People (magazine)|People]] |title=Ace in the Hole Stefania Follini Never Caved in |date=June 12, 1989 |first1=Tim |last1=Allis |last2=Haederle |first2=Michael }}</ref> or 15<ref name="AP 1"/> —only two months from the start of the experiment instead of the four that had actually transpired.<ref name="New York 1"/> She was described as "looking pale and thin" after coming out from the cave.<ref name="Chicago 1"/> Having spent about 130 days in the cave, she broke the world record for women for the most number of days spent in isolation in a cave.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |title=Cave woman ending her isolation |date=May 23, 1989 |page=7 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1696&dat=19890523&id=cvsaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GkgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6933,4722599 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Circadian rhythm]] * [[Maurizio Montalbini]] * [[Michel Siffre]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-100 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1994-016A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1994-016A|title=Navstar 2A-15|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 23027 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIA]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|1816|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|10 March 1994, 03:40:01|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II]] 7925-9.5,}} D226 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_slot = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|19986|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20315|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.9 degrees | orbit_period = 716.69 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-100''', also known as '''GPS IIA-15''', '''GPS II-24''' and '''GPS SVN-36''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the fifteenth of nineteen [[GPS Block IIA|Block IIA]] GPS satellites to be launched. USA-100 was launched at 03:40:01 UTC on 10 March 1994, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D226, flying in the 7925-9.5 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} and placed USA-100 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2a.htm|title=GPS-2A (Navstar-2A)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 15 April 1994, USA-100 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|19986|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20315|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 716.69 minutes, and 54.9 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} It broadcasts the PRN 06 signal, and operates in slot 1 of plane C of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/project/navstar.htm|title=Navstar|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]|first=Mark|last=Wade|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite has a mass of {{convert|1816|kg}}. It had a design life of 7.5 years, but it remained in service until February 2014, shortly after the launch of [[USA-248]]. == References == {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1994}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1994]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}
